revision.text:
{{about|the film|other uses|Jurassic Park III (disambiguation)}} {{redirect-distinguish|JP3|JP-3}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Jurassic Park III | image = Jurassic Park III poster.jpg | alt = Film poster with a logo at center of a skeleton of a ''Spinosaurus'', with its mouth wide open and hands lifted up. The logo's background is red, and right below it is the film's title. A shadow covers a large portion of the film poster in the shape of a flying ''Pteranodon''. At the bottom of the image are the credits and release date. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Joe Johnston]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Kathleen Kennedy (producer)|Kathleen Kennedy]] * [[Larry J. Franco|Larry Franco]] }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[Peter Buchman]] * [[Alexander Payne]] * [[Jim Taylor (writer)|Jim Taylor]] }} | based on = {{Based on|[[List of Jurassic Park characters|Characters]]|[[Michael Crichton]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Sam Neill]] * [[William H. Macy]] * [[T√©a Leoni]] * [[Alessandro Nivola]] * [[Trevor Morgan (actor)|Trevor Morgan]] * [[Michael Jeter]] }} | music = [[Don Davis (composer)|Don Davis]] | cinematography = [[Shelly Johnson (cinematographer)|Shelly Johnson]] | editing = [[Robert Dalva]] | studio = [[Amblin Entertainment]] | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2001|7|16|[[Universal Amphitheatre]]|2001|7|18|[[United States]]}} | runtime = 92 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 92:29--><ref>{{cite web |title=Jurassic Park III |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/jurassic-park-iii-2001-0 |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $93 million<ref name="BOM"/> | gross = $368.8 million<ref name="BOM"/> }}
'''''Jurassic Park III''''' is a 2001 American [[Science fiction film|science fiction]] [[adventure film]] and the third installment in the [[Jurassic Park|''Jurassic Park'' film series]]. The film stars [[Sam Neill]], [[William H. Macy]], [[T√©a Leoni]], [[Alessandro Nivola]], [[Trevor Morgan (actor)|Trevor Morgan]], and [[Michael Jeter]]. It is the first film in the series [[Steven Spielberg]] did not direct; neither was it based on a book by [[Michael Crichton]], although numerous scenes in the film were taken from Crichton's novels ''[[Jurassic Park (novel)|Jurassic Park]]'' and ''[[The Lost World (Crichton novel)|The Lost World]]''. Events depicted in the film take place on [[Isla Sorna]], an island off [[Central America]]'s Pacific coast, where a divorced couple have tricked [[Alan Grant (Jurassic Park character)|Dr. Alan Grant]] into helping them find their son.
After the success of Spielberg's film ''[[Jurassic Park (film)|Jurassic Park]]'', [[Joe Johnston]] expressed interest in directing a sequel. Spielberg gave Johnston permission to direct a third film in the series, if there was to be one. Production of ''Jurassic Park III'' began on August 30, 2000. Despite mixed reviews from critics, the film was successful at the box office, grossing $368 million worldwide. A sequel, ''[[Jurassic World]]'', was released on June 12, 2015.
==Plot== <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, plot summaries for featured films are set between 400-700 words. -->
Ben Hildebrand and 12-year-old Eric Kirby go parasailing, tethered to a boat, in the waters around [[Jurassic Park#InGen|Isla Sorna]]. The boat's crew mysteriously disappears, forcing Ben to detach the line. He and Eric drift towards the island.
In the United States, paleontologist and [[Jurassic Park (film)|Jurassic Park]] survivor Dr. Alan Grant has made a new discovery about the intelligence of ''[[Velociraptor]]s'', but struggles to secure funding for his research because of [[The Lost World: Jurassic Park|an incident at San Diego]] that has revealed the existence of the [[De-extinction#Cloning|de-extinct]] dinosaurs. Grant discusses his discovery of a resonating [[larynx]] on a fossilized raptor remains with his former lover and colleague Dr. Ellie Sattler. This, and his experience at Jurassic Park, leads him to believe the original ''Velociraptors'' were socially sophisticated. He hypothesizes that if they had not gone extinct and continued to evolve, their descendants‚Äîrather than humans‚Äî would have become Earth's dominant species. His assistant Billy Brennan uses a [[3D printing|3D printer]] to replicate the ''Velociraptor'' larynx.
Paul and Amanda Kirby offer funding for Grant's research if he will fly them around Isla Sorna. Grant reluctantly agrees and flies there with Paul, Amanda, Billy, and the Kirbys' mercenary associates Udesky, Cooper, and their pilot Nash. During the flight, Grant learns that the Kirbys plan to land on the island; he protests but Cooper knocks him unconscious.
Grant awakens to discover they have landed. A ''[[Spinosaurus]]'' approaches the group, who board the plane to escape without Cooper. The ''Spinosaurus'' devours Cooper on the runway and the plane crashes into the forest. The ''Spinosaurus'' destroys the plane, killing Nash. Fleeing, the survivors briefly lose the ''Spinosaurus'' but encounter a ''[[Tyrannosaurus|Tyrannosaurus rex]]''. The ''Spinosaurus'' returns but the group escapes while the two dinosaurs fight. The ''Spinosaurus'' breaks the ''T. rex''{{'}}s neck.
Grant learns the Kirbys are a middle-class, divorced couple who are looking for their son Eric and Amanda's boyfriend Ben, who are missing on the island. The group finds the parasail attached to Ben's corpse. They take the parasail and then encounter raptor nests, and find an abandoned InGen compound. A raptor chases them and summons the rest of its pack. The humans flee into a herd of ''[[Corythosaurus]]'' and ''[[Parasaurolophus]]'', causing a stampede, and separating Grant and Udesky from the others. Raptors attack Udesky in an attempt to lure the others out of a tree. The raptors almost kill Amanda when she tries to descend to help Udesky. The raptors' trap fails and they kill Udesky before departing.
Elsewhere, Grant watches the raptors communicating and suspects they are searching for something. They corner him but is rescued by Eric, who survives in an overturned water truck. The next day, Grant and Eric hear Paul's satellite telephone ringing, and are reunited with Billy and the Kirbys. The group is then chased by the ''Spinosaurus'' that killed Nash.
After the group escapes, Grant discovers Billy has taken two raptor eggs to use for funding, which provoked the raptor attacks. Grant decides to keep the eggs to ensure the group's survival. The group unknowingly enters a large aviary used to house ''[[Pteranodon]]s'', which attack the group and fly away with Eric. Billy rescues Eric using Ben's parasail, but is then attacked and apparently killed by the ''Pteranodons''. The rest of the group escapes the aviary, leaving the door unlocked. They find a boat and make their way down a river.
That night, the group retrieves the ringing telephone, which is buried in the feces of the ''Spinosaurus''. Grant tries to contact Sattler but the ''Spinosaurus'' attacks the boat. Grant ignites the boat's fuel and burns the ''Spinosaurus'', causing it to flee. The next day, the group makes its way towards the coast but are surrounded by the raptors. They surrender the eggs to the raptors while Grant uses the replica raptor larynx to confuse the pack, which runs off with the eggs.
The group reach the coast and find that Sattler had called in the [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]] and the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] to rescue them. They discover that Billy, while seriously injured, is still alive and has also been rescued. As they leave the island, they see the ''Pteranodons'' flying free.
==Cast== ===Characters=== {{main|List of Jurassic Park characters}} {{Cast listing|* [[Sam Neill]] as [[List of Jurassic Park characters#Dr. Alan Grant|Dr. Alan Grant]] * [[William H. Macy]] as Paul Kirby * [[T√©a Leoni]] as Amanda Kirby * [[Alessandro Nivola]] as Billy Brennan * [[Trevor Morgan (actor)|Trevor Morgan]] as Eric Kirby * [[Michael Jeter]] as Udesky * [[John Diehl]] as Cooper * [[Bruce A. Young]] as Nash * [[Laura Dern]] as Ellie<!-- No surname mentioned or credited --> * [[Taylor Nichols]] as Mark<!-- No surname mentioned or credited --> * [[Mark Harelik]] as Ben Hildebrand * [[Julio Oscar Mechoso]] as Enrique Cardoso * Blake Bryan as Charlie<!-- No surname mentioned or credited --> }}
===Creatures on screen=== {{main|List of cloned animals in Jurassic Park}} [[File:Spinosauridae_Size_Diagram_by_PaleoGeek.svg|thumb|right|Size comparison of ''[[Spinosaurus]]'' (red), ''[[Suchomimus]]'' (green), ''[[Baryonyx]]'' (yellow), and ''[[Irritator]]'' (blue) with a human]]
In a deviation from the previous films, the ''[[Spinosaurus]]'' is considered the primary antagonist;<ref>{{cite news|title=Jurassic Park III |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117798505.html?categoryid=31&cs=1 |accessdate=July 9, 2007 | first=Derek | last=Elley | date=July 17, 2001}}</ref> Johnston stated, "A lot of dinosaurs have a very similar silhouette to the ''T-Rex'' ... and we wanted the audience to instantly recognize this as something else".<ref name="prodnotes">{{cite web|accessdate=July 16, 2008 |title=Production Notes |website=Cinema Review |url=http://www.cinemareview.com/production.asp?prodid=1429}}</ref> The silhouette of the ''Spinosaurus'' is shown behind that of the ''Pteranodon''on the film's promotional poster, taking the place of the ''Tyrannosaurus'' that had been used in the previous films' posters. ''[[Baryonyx]]'' was originally considered to be the "[[big bad]]" before ''Spinosaurus'' was chosen, and early concept posters reflected this. Within the film's dialogue, Billy interprets the animal he encounters as a ''Baryonyx'' or a ''[[Suchomimus]]'', but Dr. Grant corrects his analysis based on its size and its sail.<ref name=making />
Because of new discoveries and theories in the field of paleontology, several dinosaurs are portrayed differently in this film than in previous ones. Discoveries suggesting ''Velociraptor'' were feathered prompted the addition of quill-like structures on the head and neck of the males in the film. "We've found evidence that ''Velociraptors'' had feathers, or feather-like structures, and we've incorporated that into the new look of the raptor", said paleontologist [[Jack Horner (paleontologist)|Jack Horner]], the film's technical adviser.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinema.com/articles/522/jurassic-park-3-production-notes.phtml|title=Jurassic Park 3: Production Notes|website=Cinema.com|access-date=June 3, 2016}}</ref>
Spielberg insisted that Johnston include ''Pteranodons'', which were removed from the previous films for budget reasons, in ''Jurassic Park III''.<ref name=Jul01/> An aquatic reptile was also featured in the first draft but was removed from the final script.<ref name=Jul01/> The creatures were depicted using a combination of [[animatronics]] and [[Computer generated imagery|CGI]] special effects.<ref name="prodnotes" /> The following creatures appear in the film: {{Cast listing|* ''[[Ankylosaurus]]'' * ''[[Brachiosaurus]]'' * ''[[Ceratosaurus]]'' * ''[[Compsognathus]]'' * ''[[Corythosaurus]]'' * ''[[Parasaurolophus]]'' * ''[[Pteranodon]]'' * ''[[Spinosaurus]]'' * ''[[Stegosaurus]]'' * ''[[Triceratops]]'' * ''[[Tyrannosaurus]]'' * ''[[Velociraptor]]'' }}
==Production==
===Early development=== [[Joe Johnston]] had been interested in directing the sequel to ''[[Jurassic Park (film)|Jurassic Park]]''; he approached Spielberg, a friend of his, about the project. While Spielberg wanted to direct the first sequel, he agreed Johnston could direct a possible third film.<ref name=making>{{cite video|title=The Making of Jurassic Park III |format=DVD |publisher=[[Universal Pictures]] |year=2005}}</ref> The second film, entitled ''[[The Lost World: Jurassic Park]]'', includes a scene showing a ''Tyrannosaurus'' rampaging through [[San Diego]]; Spielberg had intended to use this scene for a third film but later decided to add it into the second film after realizing he probably would not direct another film in the series.<ref name= time>{{cite news|url= http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,986365,00.html|title= Cinema: I Wanted to See a T. rex Stomping Down a Street|last= Ressner|first= Jeffrey|date= May 19, 1997|work= [[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|access-date= November 12, 2015}}{{subscription required}}</ref> After the release of the second film in May 1997, Spielberg was busy with other projects; when asked about the possibility of a third ''Jurassic Park'' film, he responded, "It would give me a tremendous ... headache just to think about it".<ref>{{cite news|url= https://variety.com/1997/voices/columns/spielberg-adds-joke-to-japanese-world-1117863077/|title= Spielberg adds joke to Japanese 'World'|last= Archerd|first= Army|date= May 28, 1997|work= Variety|access-date= November 12, 2015}}</ref>
===Pre-production=== Universal Pictures announced the film on June 29, 1998, with Spielberg as a producer. [[Michael Crichton]] was reportedly going to collaborate with Spielberg to create a storyline and write a script. The film was set for release in mid-2000.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://variety.com/1998/film/news/jurassic-3-slated-by-u-1117478032/ |title= ‚ÄòJurassic 3‚Ä≤ slated by U; Spielberg, Crichton to pen pic |work= Variety |date= June 30, 1998|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Dan|last= Cox}}</ref> Spielberg initially devised a story involving Dr. Alan Grant, who was discovered to have been living on one of [[Jurassic Park#InGen|InGen]]'s islands. According to Johnston, "He'd snuck in, after not being allowed in to research the dinosaurs, and was living in a tree like Robinson Crusoe. But I couldn't imagine this guy wanting to get back on any island that had dinosaurs in it after the first movie."<ref name=Jul01>{{cite web|url=http://www.dansjp3page.com/oldnews31.asp|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010628233556/http://www.dansjp3page.com/oldnews31.asp|title= Johnston on Underwater Dinos, Spielberg's JP3 Idea|date=June 10, 2001|archivedate=June 28, 2001|website=DansJP3Page.com|publisher=[[Movieline]]}}</ref>
In June 1999, Craig Rosenberg began writing the first draft of the script, which involved teenagers becoming marooned on Isla Sorna.<ref name=about>{{cite web|accessdate=July 27, 2011 |url=http://actionadventure.about.com/library/weekly/2001/aa071601a.htm |title=Jumanji's Joe Johnston Joins Jurassic |website=[[About.com]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060305202525/http://actionadventure.about.com/library/weekly/2001/aa071601a.htm |archivedate=March 5, 2006 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref> Johnston was announced as the film's director in August 1999, with Rosenberg still attached. Production was expected to begin in early 2000.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://variety.com/1999/film/news/jurassic-redux-1117750090/ |title= Johnston to direct third U pic |work= Variety |date= August 5, 1999|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Chris |last= Petrikin}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|accessdate=July 16, 2008 |url=http://www.cnn.com/SHOWBIZ/News/9908/06/showbuzz/ |title=Spielberg dodges directing 'Jurassic 3' |work=CNN |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061206144247/http://www.cnn.com/SHOWBIZ/News/9908/06/showbuzz/ |archivedate = December 6, 2006}}</ref> Rosenberg's draft about teenagers on Isla Sorna was rejected in September 1999.<ref name=DVD/> According to Johnston it was "not a badly written script";<ref name=about/> he also said, "It read like a bad episode of ''Friends''".<ref name=DVD/> By December 1999, new writers had been hired to devise a better story for the film.<ref name=DVD>{{cite web |url= http://www.dvdfile.com/news/special_report/in_the_round/jurassicpark/index.html|title= Evolution of the dinos - Ten questions with Joe Johnston|website= DVDFile.com|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20020103070043/http://www.dvdfile.com/news/special_report/in_the_round/jurassicpark/evolution_1.html|archive-date= January 3, 2002|page=1{{ndash}}2}}</ref>
The film's second script involved a ''[[Pteranodon]]'' escaping from Isla Sorna and causing a spate of mysterious killings on the mainland, which was to be investigated by Alan Grant and other characters including Billy Brennan, a naturalist named Simone, a tough [[military attach√©]], and wealthy Paul Roby and his teenage son Miles. Grant's group crash-lands on the island while a parallel investigation is done on the mainland. The aviary sequence and laboratory set piece were initially much longer and more complex, and included a ''[[Velociraptor]]'' stealthily entering a hatchery where the team spends the night. Sets, costumes, and props were built for this script.<ref name=making /><ref name=about/><ref name=DVD/>
In February 2000, filming was reportedly set to begin in [[Fiordland, New Zealand]], around the end of the month.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.aint-it-cool-news.com/display.cgi?id=5124 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20000303142549/http://www.aint-it-cool-news.com/display.cgi?id=5124 |title= JURASSIC PARK 3.... some news and some musings...|website= Aint-It-Cool-News.com |date= February 1, 2000 |archivedate= March 3, 2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.aint-it-cool-news.com/display.cgi?id=5135 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20000304130923/http://www.aint-it-cool-news.com/display.cgi?id=5135 |title= Further Information On JURASSIC PARK 3 |website= Aint-It-Cool-News.com |date= February 2, 2000 |archivedate= March 4, 2000}}</ref> Scenes were originally planned to be filmed there for ''[[The Lost World: Jurassic Park]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1996-10-25/entertainment/9610230218_1_jurassic-park-jim-carrey-dennis-hopper |title= Scene Is Set For 'Jurassic Park' Sequel |work= Sun-Sentinel |date= October 25, 1996|accessdate= November 10, 2014}}</ref> In March 2000, [[Maui, Hawaii]], was reportedly chosen instead of New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/03/29/location-news-trailer-rumor |title= Location News & Trailer Rumor |website= IGN.com |date= March 29, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Steve |last= Head}}</ref> Sam Neill signed to the project in June 2000; the 18-week filming schedule was expected to begin by August that year, with a projected release in July 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://variety.com/2000/film/news/neill-to-reprise-jurassic-role-1117783139/ |title= Neill to reprise ‚ÄòJurassic‚Äô role; Third installment to begin shooting July/Aug |work= Variety |date= June 28, 2000|accessdate=November 10, 2014|first= Dave |last= McNary}}</ref> Macy originally turned down his role due to scheduling conflicts.<ref name= July20 >{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/07/20/rewrites-and-new-casting-for-jurassic-park-3 |title= Rewrites and New Casting For Jurassic Park 3|website= IGN.com |date= July 20, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Scott|last= Brake}}</ref> Trevor Morgan and T√©a Leoni were cast in August 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/08/09/jurassic-park-3-the-casting-continues |title= Jurassic Park 3, The Casting Continues|website= IGN.com|date= August 9, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Steve|last= Head}}</ref> Utah's [[Dinosaur National Monument]] and a military base at [[Oahu]] were being considered as filming locations.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/08/16/jurassic-park-3-and-the-dinosaur-quarry |title= Jurassic Park 3 and the Dinosaur Quarry |website= IGN.com |date= August 16, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Steve|last= Head}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/08/07/jurassic-park-3-seeks-military-base |title= Jurassic Park 3 Seeks Military Base|website= IGN.com|date= August 7, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Steve|last= Head}}</ref> During the pre-production phase, concept artists created advertising for the film using a working titles including ''Jurassic Park: Extinction'' and ''Jurassic Park: Breakout''.<ref>{{cite video|title=Jurassic Park III |year=2001 |medium=DVD}}</ref>
Five weeks before filming began,<ref name=making /> Johnston and Spielberg rejected the entire script because they were dissatisfied with it; $18 million had already been spent on the film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lucasfilms-kathleen-kennedy-star-wars-416303?page=2&template=cap|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150309180114/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lucasfilms-kathleen-kennedy-star-wars-416303?page=2&template=cap|title=Lucasfilm's Kathleen Kennedy on 'Star Wars,' 'Lincoln' and Secret J.J. Abrams Meetings (Exclusive)|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 30, 2013|archivedate=March 9, 2015|first=Kim|last=Masters}}</ref> Johnston felt the script's story was too complicated.<ref name=DVD/> The simpler "rescue mission" plot, which had been suggested by [[David Koepp]], was used for the film instead.<ref name=making /><ref name=DVD/> Alexander Payne and Jim Taylor began rewriting the script in July 2000.<ref name= July20 />
===Filming=== Johnston said the script was never finished during production: "We shot pages that eventually went into the final script but we didn't have a document".<ref name=about/> Principal photography began on August 30, 2000, at [[Dillingham Airfield]] in [[Mokulƒìia, Hawaii]].<ref name= bulletin >{{cite news|url= http://starbulletin.com/2000/08/25/features/story2.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20001018092023/http://starbulletin.com/2000/08/25/features/story2.html |title= Cameras roll soon for Jurassic Park III |work= Honolulu Star-Bulletin |date= August 25, 2000|archivedate= October 18, 2000|first= Tim|last= Ryan}}</ref> Macy, commenting on the slow pace of filming the script, said "we would do a quarter-page‚Äìsome days, an eighth of a page. And that would be a full 12-hour day."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theonionavclub.com/avclub3720/avfeature_3720.html|archive-url= https://archive.is/20010605234324/http://www.theonionavclub.com/avclub3720/avfeature_3720.html|dead-url= yes|archive-date= June 5, 2001|title= William H. Macy interview|last= Tobias|first= Scott|date= May 30, 2001|website= [[The A.V. Club]]}}</ref>
Filming continued on [[Oahu]] until September 9.<ref name= advertiser >{{cite web|url= http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/2000/Sep/02/92localnews19.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20001018022934/http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/2000/Sep/02/92localnews19.html|title= Media gain access to 'Jurassic Park III' set |website= The Honolulu Advertiser |date= September 2, 2000|archivedate= October 18, 2000|first= Elizabeth |last= Kieszkowski}}</ref> Aerial footage of [[Molokai]]'s North Shore cliffs was then filmed over the next two days, which was followed by a week of filming in [[Kauai]].<ref name= bulletin /><ref>{{cite news|url= http://starbulletin.com/2000/09/04/news/story2.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20010625071838/http://starbulletin.com/2000/09/04/news/story2.html |title= Film producers catch aloha spirit |work= Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date= September 4, 2000 |archivedate= June 25, 2001|first= Gregg |last= K. Kakesako}}</ref> Filming in Hawaii concluded on September 20, 2000.<ref name= advertiser /> Production then moved to [[California]]; [[John August]] was hired to do uncredited work on the script in September 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/09/21/flying-dinos-for-jurassic-park-3 |title= Flying Dinos for Jurassic Park 3?|website= IGN.com |date= September 21, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Steve|last= Head}}</ref> Scenes were filmed at [[Occidental College]] in [[Los Angeles]] on October 10, 2000.<ref name= IGN >{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/10/24/jurassic-park-3-on-the-studio-backlot |title= Jurassic Park 3 on the Studio Backlot|website= IGN.com|date= October 24, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Steve|last= Head}}</ref>
Scenes were filmed at Center Bay Studios in Los Angeles at the end of October.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/10/31/jurassic-park-3-at-center-bay-studios |title= Jurassic Park 3 at Center Bay Studios|website= IGN.com |date= October 31, 2000|accessdate= November 10, 2014|first= Steve |last= Head}}</ref> Other filming locations in California included [[South Pasadena, California|South Pasadena]] and a rock quarry in [[Irwindale]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.cinemareview.com/production.asp?prodid=1430 |title= Jurassic Park III production notes: Dinos Everywhere |website= CinemaReview.com |accessdate= November 10, 2014}}</ref> Filming also took place at Universal Studios' backlot in Los Angeles.<ref name= IGN /> Production returned to Hawaii in January 2001 to film the movie's ending, which had not be written at the time of the previous Hawaiian shoot. The ending was filmed on Kauai's Pila'a Beach.<ref name= about />
The storyline contains minor scenes taken from Crichton's novels ''Jurassic Park'' and ''The Lost World'', such as the ''Pteranodon'' aviary and the use of a boat, that did not appear in these books' film adaptations.[[Laura Dern]]'s cameo was filmed in a day.<ref name=DVD/> In an earlier draft, Neill and Dern's characters were a couple in the process of splitting up.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.suntimes.com/output/show/cst-ftr-dino17.html|title= New dinosaur is bigger and badder|last= Pearlman|first= Cindy|date= July 17, 2001|work= Chicago Sun-Times|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20010719115831/http://www.suntimes.com/output/show/cst-ftr-dino17.html|archive-date= July 19, 2001}}</ref> Johnston said, "I didn't want to see them as a couple anymore. For one thing, I don't think they look like a couple. It would be uncomfortable to still see them together. And Laura Dern doesn't look like she's aged for the past fifteen years!"<ref name=DVD/> The film's longest rough cut without credits was approximately 96 minutes long; According to Johnston, "We lost maybe 8 minutes, so it was never really that long".<ref name=DVD/>
===Music=== {{main|Jurassic Park III (film score)}} Composer [[John Williams]] was busy writing the music for Spielberg's film ''[[A.I. Artificial Intelligence]]''; he recommended [[Don Davis (composer)|Don Davis]] to write the [[Jurassic Park III (film score)|''Jurassic Park III'' score]]. Williams' original themes and several new ones‚Äîsuch as one for the ''Spinosaurus'' that focused on low sounds, with tubas, trombones, and timpani‚Äîwere integrated into the score. The fight between the ''Spinosaurus'' and the ''Tyrannosaurus'', which Davis compared to [[King Kong]]'s fight with dinosaur in [[King Kong (1933 film)|the 1933 film]], juxtaposes the ''Spinosaurus'' theme with the one Williams wrote for the ''T. rex''.<ref>{{cite video|title=The Sounds of Jurassic Park III|location=Jurassic Park III Blu-Ray|publisher=Universal Home Video}}</ref> In addition, "Big Hat, No Cattle", a song by [[Randy Newman]], was used in a restaurant scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/301/301714p1.html|title=Composer Don Davis Talks Jurassic Park III and the Matrix Sequels|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=July 25, 2001|first=Kenneth|last=Plume|accessdate=July 27, 2011}}</ref>
==Release== ''Jurassic Park III'' premiered at the [[Universal Amphitheater]] in Los Angeles, California, on July 16, 2001;<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/07/10/jurassic-park-iiis-west-coast-premiere|title= Jurassic Park III's West Coast Premiere|last= Head|first= Steve|date= July 10, 2001|website= IGN|access-date= November 13, 2015}}</ref> two days later the film was released in the United States and other countries. The film earned $181,171,875 in the United States and $368,780,809 worldwide, making it the eighth-highest-grossing film of the year worldwide.<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |title=Jurassic Park III (2001) |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=jurassicpark3.htm |website=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=March 5, 2009}}</ref> It is the lowest-grossing ''Jurassic Park'' film in the series. The [[Jurassic Park III (film score)|soundtrack]] was released in July 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundtrack.net/albums/database/?id=2788 |title=''Jurassic Park III'' soundtrack valued at $12.99 |website=Soundtrack.net |accessdate=May 17, 2007}}</ref>
===Home media=== The film was released on [[VHS]] and [[DVD]] on December 11, 2001.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jurassic Park III |publisher=IGN |date=December 12, 2001 |url=http://dvd.ign.com/objects/383/383315.html |accessdate=July 9, 2007}}</ref> It was re-released with both sequels in December 2001<ref>{{cite web|title=Jurassic Park Trilogy |publisher=IGN |url=http://uk.dvd.ign.com/objects/791/791439.html |accessdate=March 6, 2007}}</ref> as the ''Jurassic Park Trilogy'', and as the ''Jurassic Park Adventure Pack'' in November 2005.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jurassic Park Adventure Pack |website=IGN |date=November 17, 2005 |url=http://uk.dvd.ign.com/articles/667/667943p1.html |accessdate=March 6, 2007}}</ref> It has also been released as a two-disc DVD set alongside ''[[Hulk (film)|Hulk]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jurassic Park III released with Hulk |website=[[Amazon.com]] |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0000Y418I |accessdate=March 6, 2007}}</ref> In 2011, the film was released on [[Blu-ray]] as part of the ''Jurassic Park: Ultimate Trilogy'' Blu-ray collection.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shaffer|first=R.L.|title=Jurassic Park: Ultimate Trilogy Blu-ray Review|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2011/10/25/jurassic-park-ultimate-trilogy-blu-ray-review|website=IGN|accessdate=May 22, 2018|date=October 25, 2011}}</ref> ''Jurassic Park III'' is also included in the ''Jurassic Park'' [[4K resolution|4K]] [[Ultra-high-definition television|UHD]] Blu-Ray collection, which was released on May 22, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ultrahd.highdefdigest.com/57208/jurassicparkcollection4kultrahdbluray.html|title=High Def Digest {{!}} Blu-ray and Games News and Reviews in High Definition|website=ultrahd.highdefdigest.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180523095506/https://ultrahd.highdefdigest.com/57208/jurassicparkcollection4kultrahdbluray.html|archive-date=May 23, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Critical response=== {{Anchor|Critics|Critical response}} ''Jurassic Park III'' has received mixed reviews from critics. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a 50% rating based on 162 reviews, with an average rating of 5.2/10. The site's consensus states; "''Jurassic Park III'' is darker and faster than its predecessors, but that doesn't quite compensate for the franchise's continuing creative decline".<ref>{{cite web|title=Jurassic Park III |website= [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/jurassic_park_iii/ |accessdate=July 8, 2007}}</ref> It has a score of 42 out of 100 on [[Metacritic]], indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/video/titles/jurassicpark3 |title=Jurassic Park III: Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=May 15, 2007}}</ref> On both sites, it is the lowest-rated film of the ''Jurassic Park'' franchise.
''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'}}s [[Owen Gleiberman]], who praised the previous ''Jurassic Park'' films, awarded the third film a C grade, writing "''Jurassic Park III'' has no pretensions to be anything more than a goose-bumpy fantasy theme-park ride for kids, but it's such a routine ride. Spielberg's wizardry is gone, and his balletic light touch as well, and that gives too much of this 90-minute movie over to the duller-than-dull characters."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20609141_168187,00.html | work=Entertainment Weekly | title=News Review: Jurassic Park III | date=August 9, 2006}}</ref> Derek Elley of ''Variety Reviews'' called the film "an all-action, helter-skelter, don't-forget-to-buy-the-computer-game ride that makes the two previous installments look like models of classic filmmaking".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117798505?refcatid=31 | work=Variety | first=Derek | last=Elley | title=Jurassic Park III | date=July 17, 2001}}</ref> Ben Varkontine of [[PopMatters]] called it "not as good a ride as the first, but a damn sight better than the second".<ref>{{cite news |title=Jurassic Park III |work=PopMatters |url=http://popmatters.com/film/reviews/j/jurassic-park-iii.shtml |accessdate=July 8, 2007 |author=Varkontine, Ben |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070903231508/http://www.popmatters.com/film/reviews/j/jurassic-park-iii.shtml |archivedate=September 3, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Much of the criticism was leveled at the plot as being simply a chase movie with no character development; ''Apollo Movie Guide'' panned the film as being "almost the same as the first movie" with "no need for new ideas or even a script".<ref>{{cite news|title=Jurassic Park III |work=Apollo Movie Guide |url=http://www.apolloguide.com/mov_fullrev.asp?CID=3331 |accessdate=July 8, 2007 |author=Webster, Brian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927002654/http://www.apolloguide.com/mov_fullrev.asp?CID=3331 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df= }}</ref> ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' magazine gave the film 3 stars out of 5, calling it "short, scrappy and intermittently scary".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/review.asp?DVDID=7645|title= Review of Jurassic Park 3 |work=EmpireOnline}}</ref>
On ''[[Ebert and Roeper]]'', [[Richard Roeper]] gave it a Thumbs Down while [[Roger Ebert]] awarded a Thumbs Up.<ref>{{cite web|title=''Ebert and Roeper'' Jurassic Park III|website=Buena Vista Entertainment|url=http://bventertainment.go.com/tv/buenavista/atm/reviews.html?sec=1&subsec=2818|accessdate=September 11, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> In a subsequent review, Ebert called it "the best blockbuster of the Summer".<ref>{{cite web|title=''Ebert and Roeper'' Planet of the Apes|website=Buena Vista Entertainment|url=http://bventertainment.go.com/tv/buenavista/atm/reviews.html?sec=1&subsec=2820|accessdate=September 11, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> In his review, Ebert gave the film three stars and said it "is not as awe-inspiring as the first film or as elaborate as the second, but in its own B-movie way it's a nice little thrill machine". He also wrote, "I can't praise it for its art, but I must not neglect its craft, and on that basis I recommend it".<ref>{{cite news|title=Jurassic Park 3 review |work=Chicago Sun-Times |first=Roger |last=Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |url=http://www.suntimes.com/output/ebert1/cst-ftr-rog18f.html |date=July 18, 2001 |accessdate=October 14, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010912191432/http://www.suntimes.com/output/ebert1/cst-ftr-rog18f.html |archivedate=September 12, 2001 }}</ref> Paleontologist [[Robert T. Bakker]], an early pioneer of the [[dinosaur-bird connection]], said the feathers quills added to the ''[[Velociraptor]]'' for ''Jurassic Park III'' "looked like a [[roadrunner]]'s toupee", but conceded that feathers are difficult subjects for computer animation and speculated that ''[[Jurassic World|Jurassic Park IV]]'''s raptors would have more realistic with plumage.<ref name="bakker-hitchcock">Bakker, R. 2004. "Dinosaurs Acting Like Birds, and Vice Versa ‚Äì An Homage to the Reverend Edward Hitchcock, First Director of the Massachusetts Geological Survey" in Feathered Dragons. Currie, P.; Koppelhus, E.; Shugar, M.; Wright J. eds. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. pp. 1-11.</ref> In 2002, Crichton said he had not watched the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crichton-official.com/faqsmain.htm |title=Frequently Asked Questions |website=Crichton-Official.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020602041358/http://www.crichton-official.com/faqsmain.htm |archive-date=June 2, 2002 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref>
===Accolades=== {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- ! scope="col"| Award ! scope="col"|Date of ceremony ! scope="col"| Category ! scope="col"| Recipient(s) ! scope="col"| Result ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| {{Abbr|Ref(s)|Reference(s)}} |- !scope="row" | [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI Film Awards]] | May 15, 2002 | Best Music | [[Don Davis (composer)|Don Davis]] and [[John Williams]] |{{Won}} |<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bmi.com/news/entry/20020515_top_film_tv_cable_composers_honored_at_bmis_annual_film_tv_awar |title=Top Film, TV, Cable Composers Honored at BMI‚Äôs Annual Film/TV Awards |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |website=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018134234/https://www.bmi.com/news/entry/20020515_top_film_tv_cable_composers_honored_at_bmis_annual_film_tv_awar |archive-date=October 18, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> |- !scope="row" | [[Golden Raspberry Awards]] | [[22nd Golden Raspberry Awards|March 23, 2002]] |[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or Sequel#Worst Remake or Sequel (1994-1995, 1997-1998, 2000-2005)|Worst Remake or Sequel]] ! |{{Nom}} |<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.eonline.com/news/42847/razzies-get-fingered |title=Razzies Get 'Fingered' |last=Armstrong |first=Mark |date=February 11, 2002 |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |work=[[E! Online]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180809234614/https://www.eonline.com/news/42847/razzies-get-fingered |archive-date=August 9, 2018 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> |- !scope="row" | [[Golden Reel Award (Motion Picture Sound Editors)|Golden Reel Awards]] | March 23, 2002 |Best Sound Editing ‚Äì Effects & Foley |Howell Gibbens, [[Christopher Boyes]], James Likowski, [[Frank E. Eulner]] and Ken Fischer |{{Nom}} |<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2002/film/awards/sound-editors-tap-noms-for-golden-reel-awards-1117860492/ |title=Sound editors tap noms for Golden Reel Awards |last=Hobbs |first=John |date=February 10, 2002 |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002170123/http://variety.com/2002/film/awards/sound-editors-tap-noms-for-golden-reel-awards-1117860492/ |archive-date=October 2, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> |- !scope="row" | [[Golden Trailer Awards]] | 2002 |Best Horror/Thriller Film ! |{{Nom}} |<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.goldentrailer.com/awards.gta3.php |title=WINNERS AND NOMINEES |website=[[Golden Trailer Awards]] |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120307155929/http://www.goldentrailer.com/awards.gta3.php |archivedate=March 7, 2012 |access-date=June 23, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> |- !scope="row" rowspan=2| [[Satellite Awards]] | rowspan="2" | [[6th Golden Satellite Awards|January 19, 2002]] | [[Satellite Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Visual Effects]] | Jim Mitchell, [[Stan Winston]] (uncredited), [[Danny Gordon Taylor]], [[Donald R. Elliott]], [[John Rosengrant]] |{{Nom}} | rowspan="2" | <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2001/film/awards/moulin-rouge-in-orbit-topping-satellite-noms-1117857489/ |title=‚ÄòMoulin Rouge‚Äô in orbit, topping Satellite noms |last=Berkshire |first=Geoff |date=December 17, 2001 |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706215104/https://variety.com/2001/film/awards/moulin-rouge-in-orbit-topping-satellite-noms-1117857489/ |archive-date=July 6, 2018 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> |- | [[Satellite Award for Best Sound|Best Sound]] |Howell Gibbens |{{Nom}} |- !scope="row" rowspan=2| [[Saturn Awards]] | rowspan="2" | [[28th Saturn Awards|June 10, 2002]] |[[Saturn Award for Best Science Fiction Film|Best Science Fiction Film]] ! |{{Nom}} | rowspan="2" | <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Nominees-for-28th-Annual-Saturn-Awards/99311016139883/ |title=Nominees for 28th Annual Saturn Awards |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |date=March 14, 2002 |website=[[United Press International]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002215332/https://www.upi.com/Nominees-for-28th-Annual-Saturn-Awards/99311016139883/ |archive-date=October 2, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> |- |[[Saturn Award for Best Special Effects|Best Special Effects]] |Jim Mitchell, Stan Winston (uncredited), Danny Gordon Taylor, Donald R. Elliott, John Rosengrant |{{Nom}} |- !scope="row" rowspan=3|[[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards]] | rowspan="3" | 2002 |Worst Actress |[[Tea Leoni]] |{{Nom}} | rowspan="3" | <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/2001/2001st.htm |title=2001 24th Hastings Bad Cinema Society Stinkers Awards |accessdate=March 30, 2013 |website=[[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815101727/http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/2001/2001st.htm |archivedate=August 15, 2007 }}</ref> |- |Worst Screenplay for a Film Grossing More Than $100 Million Worldwide Using Hollywood Math |[[Peter Buchman]], [[Alexander Payne]], [[Jim Taylor (writer)|Jim Taylor]], based on the book by [[Michael Crichton]] |{{Nom}} |- |Worst Sequel ! |{{Nom}} |- |}
== Marketing and merchandise == A teaser trailer was released online in September 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/09/11/jurassic-park-3-teaser-trailer-online |title= Jurassic Park 3 Teaser Trailer Online |website= IGN.com|date= September 11, 2000|accessdate= November 6, 2014|first= Steve|last= Head}}</ref> Universal avoided excessive early marketing to prevent a possible backlash; the studio believed awareness of the film was already sufficient.<ref name=may25>{{cite web |url= http://dailynews.yahoo.com/h/bpihw/20010524/en/studios_taking_cautious_tack_in_marketing_1.html|title= Studios taking cautious tack in marketing|last= Rose|first= Marla Matzer|date= May 25, 2001|website= [[Yahoo!]]|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20010612135941/http://dailynews.yahoo.com/h/bpihw/20010524/en/studios_taking_cautious_tack_in_marketing_1.html|archive-date= June 12, 2001}}</ref> Marketing began in April 2001, three months before the film's release.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://digitalmediafx.com/News2001/April/040801.html#2|title= Behind the Scenes of ''Jurassic Park 3''|date= April 8, 2001|website= Digital Media FX|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20010420233859/http://digitalmediafx.com/News2001/April/040801.html#2|archive-date= April 20, 2001}}</ref> The first footage from the film was aired during the second-season finale of ''[[Survivor (U.S. TV series)|Survivor]]'' in May 2001.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aintitcool.com/node/8890|title= First Jurassic Park III TV Spot Right Here, Baby!!!|date= May 3, 2001|website= AintItCool.com|access-date= November 12, 2015}}</ref> Promotional partners included [[Kodak]] and [[The Coca-Cola Company]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://countingdown.com/movies/jurassicpark3/movieinfo/story?item_id=15464|title= Kodak - Jurassic Park 3 Partner|date= April 2, 2001|website= CountingDown.com|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20010411082259/http://countingdown.com/movies/jurassicpark3/movieinfo/story?item_id=15464|archive-date= April 11, 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://countingdown.com/movies/jurassicpark3/movieinfo/story?item_id=14984|title= Coke announces in-theater tie-in|date= March 26, 2001|website= CountingDown.com|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20010411075822/http://countingdown.com/movies/jurassicpark3/movieinfo/story?item_id=14984|archive-date= April 11, 2001}}</ref> No fast-food promotions took place in the United States,<ref name=may25/> although children's meal toys based on the film were offered in Canadian [[Burger King]] outlets.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.countingdown.com/movies/jurassicpark3/movieinfo/story?item_id=20520|title= Burger King confirmed for fast food promotion!|date= May 20, 2001|website= CountingDown.com|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20010628054651/http://www.countingdown.com/movies/jurassicpark3/movieinfo/story?item_id=20520|archive-date= June 28, 2001}}</ref>
[[Jurassic Park video games#Jurassic Park III (2001)|Seven video games]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Jurassic Park Licensees |website=Moby Games |url=http://www.mobygames.com/game-group/jurassic-park-licensees/ |accessdate=July 6, 2007}}</ref> were released to coincide with the film, and a [[novelization]] by [[Scott Ciencin]] that was aimed at young children was published.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ciencin, Scott|title=Jurassic Park III |publisher=Random House Books for Young Readers |year=2001 |page=116 |isbn=978-0-375-81318-4}}</ref> Ciencin also wrote three children's books to tie in with the film's events: ''[[Jurassic Park Adventures: Survivor]]'', the first book, detailed the eight weeks Eric spent alone on Isla Sorna;<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Scott Ciencin|Ciencin, Scott]] |title=Survivor |publisher=Boxtree |date=June 2001 |page=116 |isbn=0-7522-1978-2}}</ref> ''[[Jurassic Park Adventures: Prey]]'' had Eric and Alan returning to Isla Sorna to rescue a group of teenage filmmakers;<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Scott Ciencin]] |title=Prey |publisher=Boxtree |date=October 2001 |page=123 |isbn=0-375-81290-3}}</ref> and ''[[Jurassic Park Adventures: Flyers]]'' involved Eric and Alan leading the ''Pteranodon'' home after they nest in a Universal Studios theme park.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Scott Ciencin|Ciencin, Scott]] |title=Flyers |publisher=Boxtree |date=March 2002 |page=128 |isbn=0-375-81291-1}}</ref>
In early 2001, Hasbro released a line of 3.75" action figures including electronic dinosaurs, humans, and vehicles, to coincide with the film's release.<ref name=JPT>{{cite web |url= http://www.jptoys.com/toy-database/jurassic-park-3/index.htm|title= Jurassic Park 3|website= JPToys.com|access-date= November 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://skyjammer.50megs.com/asm/mar2001/has_jpiii.html|title= Hasbro: Jurassic Park III|last= Lipkowitz|first= Daniel|date= 2001|work= Altered States Magazine|archive-url= https://archive.is/20010222060130/http://skyjammer.50megs.com/asm/mar2001/has_jpiii.html|archive-date= February 22, 2001}}</ref> The figures were scaled down from the original [[Kenner]] action figures from the pre-''Jurassic Park III'' toy lines.<ref name=JPT/> A line of toys were also released through the [[Lego Studios]] brand.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://skyjammer.50megs.com/asm/mar2001/lego_jpiii_mind.html|title= LEGO: Jurassic Park III, Mindstorms|last= Lipkowitz|first= Daniel|date= 2001|work= Altered States Magazine|archive-url= https://archive.is/20010222061136/http://skyjammer.50megs.com/asm/mar2001/lego_jpiii_mind.html|archive-date= February 22, 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+LEGO+Company+and+Universal+Studios+Consumer+Products+Group...-a069967113|title= The LEGO Company and Universal Studios Consumer Products Group Announce New Toys Based on Jurassic Park III.|date= February 5, 2001|website= [[The Free Library]]|access-date= November 13, 2015}}</ref> [[Playskool]] released a line of toys called Jurassic Park Junior, which were aimed at young children.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://filmforce.ign.com/news/2021.html|title= Toy Fair Day 3 ‚Äì Part 2: Jurassic Park 3, Lord of the Rings, Star Wars & More!|last= Keier|first= Helen|date= February 15, 2001|website= IGN|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20010218090130/http://filmforce.ign.com/news/2021.html|archive-date= February 18, 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.toynerd.com/index.php/2013/06/18/jurassic-park-junior-dinosaur-figures-playskool/|title= Dinosaurs even the smallest kids will love|date= June 18, 2013|website= ToyNerd.com|access-date= November 13, 2015|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151117030051/http://www.toynerd.com/index.php/2013/06/18/jurassic-park-junior-dinosaur-figures-playskool/|archivedate= November 17, 2015|df= mdy-all}}</ref> A smaller line of die-cast toys and a range of clothes were also produced. In November 2001, to promote the film's impending home media release, Universal launched a [[viral marketing]] website for Isla Travel, a fictional Isla Sorna travel agency.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.dansjp3page.com/oldnews44.asp|title= DVD Promo Site islaTravel.com Opens|date= November 27, 2001|website= DansJP3Page.com|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20020203062054/http://www.dansjp3page.com/oldnews44.asp|archive-date= February 3, 2002}}</ref>
===Cell phone promotion=== For the film's home media release, Universal partnered with cell-phone company Hop-On to produce "the world's first-disposable cell phone", which would have been available through an in-package offer upon purchase of the film.<ref name=variety>{{cite web |url= https://variety.com/2001/digital/features/dinos-phone-in-video-promotion-1117856452/|title= Dinos phone in video promotion|last= Hettrick|first= Scott|date= November 28, 2001|website= Variety|access-date= November 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://hop-on.com/jppr.html|title= Universal Studios Home Video and Hop-On Introduce the World's First Disposable, Fully Recyclable Cell Phone: The Jurassic Park Survival Cell Phone|date= November 29, 2001|website= Hop-On.com|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20020603050728/http://hop-on.com/jppr.html|archive-date= June 3, 2002}}</ref> The telephones were to be delivered free to customers who responded to a winning promotional card that was supplied with selected copies of the film.<ref name=variety/> Approximately 5,000 copies of the film contained a winning promotional card; approximately 1,000 of them were redeemed.<ref name=hmm/>
The promotion was canceled because the handsets could not be finished on time.<ref name=hmm>{{cite news|url= http://www.homemediamagazine.com/news/ijurassic-park-iiii-survival-phone-promo-is-extinct-3255|title= Jurassic Park III Survival Phone Promo Is Extinct|last= Wagner|first= Holly J.|date= June 7, 2002|work= [[Home Media Magazine]]|access-date= November 13, 2015|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20151117020549/http://www.homemediamagazine.com/news/ijurassic-park-iiii-survival-phone-promo-is-extinct-3255|archive-date= November 17, 2015|dead-url= yes|df= mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=sfc/> An investigation by the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' revealed that sample versions of Hop-On's cell phones were actually modified [[Nokia]] handsets; Hop-On was having problems with its own design.<ref name=sfc>{{cite news|url= http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Sample-new-cell-phone-really-just-modified-Nokia-2860214.php|title= Sample 'new' cell phone really just modified Nokia|last= Wallack|first= Todd|date= March 29, 2002|work= [[San Francisco Chronicle]]|access-date= November 13, 2015}}</ref> Customers who were to receive the cell phones received a $30 check and a free DVD instead.<ref name=hmm/>
==See also== * [[List of American films of 2001]] * [[List of cloned animals in Jurassic Park|List of cloned animals in ''Jurassic Park'']] * [[List of films featuring dinosaurs]]

revision.text:
'''Katagelasticism''' is a psychological condition in which a person excessively enjoys laughing at others (coined by [[Christian F. Hempelmann]] and Sean Harrigan<ref name=RuchProyer2009>{{cite journal|url=http://www.reference-global.com/doi/abs/10.1515/HUMR.2009.009|last=Ruch|first=W.|author2=R.T. Proyer|year=2009|title=Extending the study of gelotophobia: On gelotophiles and katagelasticists|journal=Humor ‚Äì International Journal of Humor Research|volume=22|issue=1‚Äì2|pages=183‚Äì212|doi=10.1515/HUMR.2009.009}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> from [[wikt:Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ±Œ≥ŒµŒªŒ±œÉœÑŒÆœÇ|Œ∫Œ±œÑŒ±Œ≥ŒµŒªŒ±œÉœÑŒÆœÇ]] (''katagelastƒìs''), [[Ancient Greek]] for "mocker"). Katagelasticists actively seek and establish situations in which they can laugh at others (at the expense of these people). There is a broad variety of things that katagelasticists would do‚Äîstarting from harmless [[pranks]] or [[word play]]s to truly embarrassing and even harmful, mean-spirited jokes.<ref name=Ruch2009>{{cite journal|url=http://www.reference-global.com/doi/abs/10.1515/HUMR.2009.009|last=Ruch|first=W.|author2=U. Beermann|author3=R.T. Proyer|year=2009|title=Investigating the humor of gelotophobes: Does feeling ridiculous equal being humorless?|journal=Humor ‚Äì International Journal of Humor Research|volume=22|issue=1‚Äì2|pages=111‚Äì143|doi=10.1515/HUMR.2009.009}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name=Ruch2009ex>{{cite journal |last=Ruch |first=W |author2=R.T. Proyer |year=2009 |title=Extending the study of gelotophobia: On gelotophiles and katagelasticists |journal=Humor: International Journal of Humor Research |volume=22 |issue=1‚Äì2 |pages=183‚Äì212 |url=http://www.reference-global.com/doi/abs/10.1515/HUMR.2009.009 |doi=10.1515/HUMR.2009.009 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> They would be of the opinion that laughing at others is part of the daily life and if others do not like being laughed at, they should just fight back.<ref name=Ruch2009/><ref name=Ruch2009ex/> For the katagelasticists it is fun laughing at others and there is almost nothing that might hinder them from doing so. For them, some people even might provoke getting laughed at (and surely deserve being laughed at).<ref name=Ruch2009/><ref name=Ruch2009ex/> This condition often makes it difficult for sufferers to gain and maintain acquaintances and romantic partners. <ref name=Ruch2009/><ref name=Ruch2009ex/>
==Research== The first academic paper to investigate this phenomenon was published in 2009.<ref name=Ruch2009/><ref name=Ruch2009ex/> Along with [[gelotophobia]] and [[gelotophilia]] it can be measured through a questionnaire that consists of 45 questions (the PhoPhiKat-45; the PhoPhiKat-30 is a short form that consists of 30 items). This is a reliable and valid instrument that has been used in a variety of studies.<ref name=Ruch2009/><ref name=Ruch2009ex/><ref>{{cite journal |last=Proyer |first=R.T. |author2=C.F. Hempelmann |author3=W. Ruch |year=2009 |title=Were they really laughed at? That much? Gelotophobes and their history of perceived derisibility |journal=Humor: International Journal of Humor Research |volume=22 |issue=1‚Äì2 |pages=213‚Äì231 |url=http://www.reference-global.com/doi/abs/10.1515/HUMR.2009.010 |doi=10.1515/HUMR.2009.010 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The questionnaire is also online for a free self-assessment in German [http://www.charakterstaerken.org here].
Gelotophobia, gelotophilia, and katagelasticism describe three different stances towards laughter and laughing at. Empirical studies with the PhoPhiKat-45 show that, of course, people can not at the same time fear and like being laughed at (i.e., be gelotophobes and gelotophiles at the same time). However, there is at least a subgroup of gelotophobes that enjoys laughing at others, despite knowing how harmful this can be.<ref name=Ruch2009/><ref name=Ruch2009ex/> Finally, gelotophilia and katagelasticism are positively related; i.e., those who enjoy being laughed at might also enjoy laughing at others.<ref name=Ruch2009/><ref name=Ruch2009ex/>
==See also== *[[Gelotophilia]] ‚Äì the joy of being laughed at *[[Gelotophobia]] ‚Äì a fear of being laughed at *[[Schadenfreude]] ‚Äì pleasure derived from the misfortunes of others
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Proyer, R. T., & Ruch, W. (2010). [http://www.psychologie-aktuell.com/fileadmin/download/ptam/1-2010/04_Proyer.pdf Dispositions towards ridicule and being laughed at: Current research on gelotophobia, gelotophilia, and katagelasticism (Editorial to Special Issue).]. Psychological Test and Assessment Modeling, 52(1), 49‚Äì59.
==External links== * [http://www.gelotophobia.org Gelotophobia Assessment and Research Association Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091219191834/http://www.gelosweb.com/ Website on Gelotophobia, by Tracey Platt] * [http://www.reference-global.com/toc/humr/22/1-2 Special Issue on Gelotophobia in Humor: International Journal of Humor Research (1-2/2008)] * [http://www.sciencenews.org/view/feature/id/45581/title/When_Humor_Humiliates When Humor Humiliates, by Susan Guidos (Science news)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120223123920/http://www.doaj.org/doaj?func=openurl&genre=journal&issn=21900493&volume=52&issue=1&date=2010 Special issue in Psychological Test and Assessment modeling entitled Dispositions towards ridicule and being laughed at: Current research on gelotophobia, gelotophilia, and katagelasticism; open access]
[[Category:Abnormal psychology]] [[Category:Anxiety disorders]] [[Category:Laughter]]

'''Keypers''' are [[toy]]s in the shape of [[animal]]s that were designed with opening compartments for children to store small items in. They were made in the 1980s by [[Tonka]] Corp.
==Overview== The Keypers characters depict animals (including a [[snail]], [[ladybug]] and [[turtle]]) and have small compartments which are intended for children to hide things in. The large adult Keypers have special keys so you can lock and unlock the compartments they have located on them. The small baby Keypers have a slit in their backs so you can squeeze, open and then hide things inside. The Keypers also have small Finders for friends. The Finders help the Keypers find lost items.
===Styles=== Various styles of Keypers were made, with many color variations depending on which country it was released in. Other variations were that some had glitter and non glittery eyes, and the adult [[bear]] even has different names depending on the [[United States|US]] or [[United Kingdom|UK]] version.
==As a collectors' item== Some Keypers items are very rare and are now sought after by collectors or for [[nostalgia|nostalgic]] reasons. Some items can be found in [[thrift store]]s, on [[online auction]] websites like [[eBay]], and on 1980s toy-selling webpages.
[[Category:Tonka brands]] [[Category:1980s toys]] [[Category:Toy figurines]] [[Category:Toy animals]]
{{Toy-stub}}

[[File:Billy Dee Williams Joan Plowright A Taste of Honey Broadway 1960.jpg|thumb|right|''[[A Taste of Honey]]'' is an influential "kitchen sink drama". In this photo of the 1960 Broadway production, Joan Plowright plays the role of Jo, a 17-year old schoolgirl who has a love affair with a black sailor (played by Billy Dee Williams).]] '''Kitchen sink realism''' (or '''kitchen sink drama''') is a [[British culture|British cultural]] movement that developed in the late 1950s and early 1960s in [[theatre]], [[art]], [[novel]]s, [[film]], and [[television play]]s, whose [[protagonists]] usually could be described as "[[angry young men]]" who were disillusioned with modern society. It used a style of [[social realism]], which depicted the domestic situations of [[working class]] Britons, living in cramped rented accommodation and spending their off-hours drinking in grimy [[pub]]s, to explore controversial social and political issues ranging from [[abortion]] to [[homelessness]]. The harsh, realistic style contrasted sharply with the [[escapism]] of the previous generation's so-called "[[well-made play]]s".
The films, plays and novels employing this style are often set in poorer industrial areas in the [[Northern England|North of England]], and use the [[Accent (dialect)|accent]]s and [[slang]] heard in those regions. The film ''[[It Always Rains on Sunday]]'' (1947) is a precursor of the genre, and the [[John Osborne]] play ''[[Look Back in Anger]]'' (1956) is thought of as the first of the genre. The gritty [[love-triangle]] of ''Look Back in Anger'', for example, takes place in a cramped, one-room flat in the [[English Midlands]]. [[Shelagh Delaney]]'s 1958 play ''[[A Taste of Honey]]'' (which was made into a [[A Taste of Honey (film)|film of the same name]] in 1961), is about a teenage schoolgirl who has an affair with a black sailor, gets pregnant, and then moves in with a gay male acquaintance; it raises issues such as class, race, gender and sexual orientation. The conventions of the genre have continued into the 2000s, finding expression in such television shows as ''[[Coronation Street]]'' and ''[[EastEnders]]''.<ref name=heilpern/>
In art, "Kitchen Sink School" was a term used by critic [[David Sylvester]] to describe painters who depicted [[social realist]]‚Äìtype scenes of domestic life.<ref>Walker, John. (1992) [http://www.artdesigncafe.com/kitchen-sink-school-1992 "Kitchen Sink School"]. ''Glossary of Art, Architecture & Design since 1945'', 3rd. ed. Retrieved 20 January 2012.</ref>
==History==
===Antecedents and influences=== The cultural movement was rooted in the ideals of social realism, an [[artistic movement]], expressed in the visual and other [[realism (arts)|realist arts]], which depicts [[working class]] activities. Many artists who subscribed to social realism were [[Painting|painter]]s with [[socialism|socialist]] political views.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} While the movement has some commonalities with [[Socialist Realism]], another style of [[realism (arts)|realism]] which was the "official art" advocated by the governments of the [[Soviet Union]] and other [[Eastern Bloc]] countries, the two had several differences. While social realism is a broader type of art that realistically depicts subjects of social concern,<ref>Todd, James G. "Social Realism". Art Terms. Museum of Modern Art, 2009.</ref> Socialist realism is characterized by the glorified depiction of socialist values, such as the emancipation of the [[proletariat]], in a realistic manner.<ref>Korin, Pavel, ‚ÄúThoughts on Art‚Äù, ''Socialist Realism in Literature and Art''. Progress Publishers, Moscow, 1971, p. 95.</ref>
Unlike Socialist realism, social realism is not an official art produced by, or under the supervision of the government. The leading characters are often '[[anti-heroes]]' rather than part of a class to be admired, as in Socialist realism.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} Typically, protagonists in social realism are dissatisfied with their working class lives and the world, rather than being idealised workers who are part of a Socialist utopia in the process of creation. As such, social realism allows more space for the [[Subject (philosophy)|subjectivity]] of the author to be displayed.
Partly, social realism developed as a reaction against [[Romanticism]]{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}, which promoted lofty concepts such as the "ineffable" beauty and truth of art and music, and even turned them into spiritual ideals. As such, social realism focused on the "ugly realities of contemporary life and sympathized with working class people, particularly the poor." (The quotation is from George Shi, of the University of Fine Arts, Valencia).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://instruct.westvalley.edu/grisham/1b_social.html |title=Social Realism |accessdate=2008-05-04 |work= }}</ref>
==Origins of the term== In the United Kingdom, the term "kitchen sink" derived from an [[Expressionism|expressionist painting]] by [[John Bratby]], which contained an image of a kitchen sink. Bratby did various kitchen and bathroom-themed paintings, including three paintings of toilets. Bratby's paintings of people often depicted the faces of his subjects as desperate and unsightly.<ref>Ian Chilvers; John Glaves-Smith (2009). A Dictionary of Modern and Contemporary Art. Oxford University Press. p. 259. {{ISBN|978-0-19-923965-8}}</ref><ref>"John Bratby 1928‚Äì1992". Tate. Retrieved 6 January 2014.</ref> Kitchen sink realism artists painted everyday objects, such as trash cans and beer bottles. The critic David Sylvester wrote an article in 1954 about trends in recent English art, calling his article "The Kitchen Sink" in reference to Bratby's picture. Sylvester argued that there was a new interest among young painters in domestic scenes, with stress on the banality of life.<ref name=heilpern/> Other artists associated with the kitchen sink style include Derrick Greaves, [[Edward Middleditch]] and [[Jack Smith (artist)|Jack Smith]].
==1950s‚Äì1960s== Before the 1950s, the [[United Kingdom]]'s [[working class]] were often depicted stereotypically in [[No√´l Coward]]'s [[Drawing room play|drawing room comedies]] and British films. Kitchen sink realism was also seen as being in opposition to the "[[well-made play]]", the kind which theatre critic [[Kenneth Tynan]] once denounced as being set in "[[Loamshire]]", of dramatists like [[Terence Rattigan]]. "Well-made plays" were a [[Drama|dramatic genre]] from [[nineteenth-century theatre]] which found its early 20th-century codification in Britain in the form of [[William Archer (critic)|William Archer]]'s ''Play-Making: A Manual of Craftmanship'' (1912),<ref>Archer, William. Playmaking: a Manual of Craftsmanship. Public domain. https://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/10865</ref> and in the United States with [[George Pierce Baker]]'s ''Dramatic Technique'' (1919).<ref>J L Styan, ''Modern Drama in Theory and Practice I'', quoted by Innes (2000, 7).</ref> Kitchen sink works were created with the intention of changing all that. Their [[politics|political]] views were initially labeled as [[Extremism|radical]], sometimes even [[anarchism|anarchic]].
[[John Osborne]]'s play ''[[Look Back In Anger]]'' (1956) depicted young men in a way that is similar to the then-contemporary "[[Angry Young Men]]" movement of film and theatre directors. The "angry young men" were a group of mostly [[working class|working]] and [[middle class]] [[United Kingdom|British]] [[playwright]]s and [[novelist]]s who became prominent in the 1950s. Following the success of the Osborne play, the label "angry young men" was later applied by British media to describe young writers who were characterised by a disillusionment with traditional [[British society]]. The hero of ''Look Back In Anger'' is a graduate, but he is working in a manual occupation. It dealt with [[social alienation]], the [[claustrophobia]] and frustrations of a provincial life on low incomes.
The impact of this work inspired [[Arnold Wesker]] and [[Shelagh Delaney]], among numerous others, to write plays of their own. The English Stage Company at the [[Royal Court Theatre]], headed by [[George Devine]] and [[Theatre Workshop]] organised by [[Joan Littlewood]] were particularly prominent in bringing these plays to public attention. Critic [[John Heilpern]] wrote that ''Look Back in Anger'' expressed such "immensity of feeling and class hatred" that it altered the course of English theatre.<ref name=heilpern>[[Heilpern, John]]. ''John Osborne: The Many Lives of the Angry Young Man'', New York: Knopf, 2007.</ref> The term "Angry theatre" was coined by critic [[John Russell Taylor]].<ref>[[John Russell Taylor]]. ''Anger and After'', 1962, London: Methuen.</ref>
This was all part of the [[British New Wave]]‚Äîa transposition of the concurrent ''[[French New Wave|nouvelle vague]]'' film movement in [[France]], some of whose works, such as ''[[The 400 Blows]]'' of 1959, also emphasised the lives of the urban proletariat. British filmmakers such as [[Tony Richardson]] and [[Lindsay Anderson]] (see also [[Free Cinema]]) channelled their vitriolic anger into film making. Confrontational films such as ''[[Saturday Night and Sunday Morning (film)|Saturday Night and Sunday Morning]]'' (1960) and ''[[A Taste of Honey (film)|A Taste of Honey]]'' (1961) were noteworthy movies in the genre. ''Saturday Night and Sunday Morning'' is about a young machinist who spends his wages at weekends on drinking and having a good time, until his affair with a married woman leads to her getting pregnant and him being beaten by her husband to the point of hospitalization. ''A Taste of Honey'' is about a 17-year old schoolgirl with an abusive, alcoholic mother. The schoolgirl starts a relationship with a black sailor and gets pregnant. After the sailor leaves on his ship, Jo moves in with a [[homosexual]] acquaintance, Geoffrey, who assumes the role of surrogate father. ''A Taste of Honey'' raises the issues of class, race, gender and sexual orientation.
Later, as many of these writers and directors diversified, kitchen sink realism was taken up by television directors who produced [[television play]]s. The single play was then a staple of the medium, and ''[[Armchair Theatre]]'' (1956‚Äì68), produced by the ITV contractor [[Associated British Corporation|ABC]], ''[[The Wednesday Play]]'' (1964‚Äì70) and ''[[Play for Today]]'' (1970‚Äì84), both BBC series, contained many works of this kind. [[Jeremy Sandford]]'s television play ''[[Cathy Come Home]]'' (1966, directed by [[Ken Loach]] for ''The Wednesday Play'' slot) for instance, addressed the then-stigmatised issue of [[homelessness]].
Kitchen sink realism was also used in the novels of [[Stan Barstow]], [[John Braine]], [[Alan Sillitoe]] and others.

[[File:Kleiton & Kledir.jpg|thumb|right|Kleiton & Kledir]] '''Kleiton & Kledir''' are a duo of [[Brazil]]ian singers and songwriters, composed of brothers Kleiton Ramil and Kledir Ramil. They are also brothers of singer-songwriter [[Vitor Ramil]].
== Biography ==
Brothers Kleiton and Kledir Ramil started their musical careers in the 1970s group "Alm√¥ndegas", with whom they recorded four albums. By the end of the decade the group dissolved and they continued as a duo. Their first album was released in 1980. Their best-known song, "Deu Pra Ti" was released in the following album. In 1989 the duo split and each of them released a solo album. Later, they reformed and released "Dois" in 1996. They still record and perform concerts across Brazil.
In 2008, preparing to record a new unreleased album that should come out in 2009. Meanwhile, continue traveling throughout Brazil with the show's CD / DVD kleiton & kledir - live, where they make a rereading of the career so successful . The album is a release Som Livre / RBS - production with the British Paul Ralphes - and received the TIM Award for Best Album of the Year in the category of popular song.
The CD and DVD "Auto-Retrato", released in 2009 is a project of new songs. The DVD, in documentary format, meets the new songs and the stories that permeate his creations, telling about the life of the double gaucho. Auto-Retrato the title track, is a conversation between two friends, where each vents and reveals its secrets.
In 2011 launch "Par ou √çmpar", her first children's CD. This work launched the following year the CD / DVD "Par ou √çmpar ao Vivo" in partnership with the Grupo Tholl, also with the participation of Fabiana Karla. The CD of the musical show odd or even received the Award of Brazilian music as Best Children's Album, during a ceremony in the City of Rio Theater on June 12, 2013, and the A√ßorianos Award for Best Children's CD, in Porto Alegre, 25 June 2013.
In 2015 is launched their new CD "Com Todas as Letras" which have participation of great writers of Rio Grande do Sul as partners in new compositions. Among the writers are names like [[Caio Fernando Abreu]], [[Luis Fernando Verissimo]], [[Martha Medeiros]], Fabricio Carpinejar, let√≠cia wierzchowski, Daniel Galera, Paul Scott, Claudia Tajes, Alcy Cheuiche and Lawrence Cazarr√©. The album is nominated for A√ßorianos Award in the Album, Composer of MPB.

'''''Live from the Artists Den''''' is a three-time New York [[Emmy]]-nominated music television series that features popular recording artists performing in non-traditional settings throughout North America. ''Live from the Artists Den'' broadcasts nationally on public television (now in its 11th season) and internationally in the United Kingdom, Latin America, China, Japan, Germany, New Zealand, and Canada.
Featured artists have included [[Adele]], [[Mumford and Sons]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Ed Sheeran]], [[Zac Brown Band]], [[Imagine Dragons]], [[Norah Jones]], [[Soundgarden]], [[Vampire Weekend]], [[Kid Rock]], [[Robert Plant]], [[The Fray]], [[Elvis Costello]], [[The National (band)|The National]], [[Ringo Starr]], [[Marina and The Diamonds]], [[Death Cab for Cutie]], and [[Alabama Shakes]]. Featured venues have included [[Graceland]], the first art museum in America, a Masonic temple, a former Archdiocese cathedral, a 1930s silent movie theater, the world‚Äôs oldest merchant sailing vessel, the [[New York Public Library]], and the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. A full listing of previously featured artists, TV episodes, and venues can be viewed at [http://artistsden.com artistsden.com].
Live CDs, DVDs, and digital downloads of Artists Den performances can be purchased online via [[iTunes]] and the [http://www.Artistsden.com Artists Den website].
On August 3, 2015, the Artists Den announced its first cinema release, ''Artists Den Presents alt-j,'' in partnership with [[Fathom Events]]. The one-night cinema event premiered in U.S. cinemas on September 2, 2015 and featured the U.K. rock band's full-length Artists Den performance at the Hollywood American Legion, plus exclusive interviews and an introduction from the band.
==Format== Each hour-long episode of ''Live from the Artists Den'' contains an intimate performance and interview with the featured artist(s). Mark Lieberman (Executive Producer) and [[Alan Light]] (Director of Programming) select artists with a reputation for impressive live performances, and locations are chosen for their historical significance, beauty, and/or sentimental value to the artist. The series differs from similar shows in that the venue is as much a distinguishing feature of the show as the performance. The audience for each intimate, invitation-only performance is selected via the official Artists Den mailing list.
"Live from the Artists Den" is a production of Artists Den Entertainment, presented by [[WLIW]] in association with [[WNET]], and is distributed nationally by [[American Public Television]]. The series is filmed in 1080 high-definition and audio is recorded using [[Apogee]]‚Äôs custom Symphony I/O 64 channel multi-track system for extraordinary sound fidelity.
