[[Dan Chupong]] | music = Terdsak Janpan | cinematography = Nuttawut Kittikun | editing = Saravut Nakajud
Nuttawut Kittikun | distributor = [[Sahamongkol Film International]] | released = {{Film date|2010|5|5}} | runtime = 95 minutes | country = Thailand | language = [[Thai language|Thai]] | budget = $5,000,000 }} '''''Ong-Bak 3''''' ({{lang-th|‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡πå‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏Å 3}}) is a 2010 Thai [[martial arts film]] directed, produced and written by [[Tony Jaa]] and [[Panna Rittikrai]]. The film's story is a follow-up to ''[[Ong Bak 2]]'', where Tien (Tony Jaa) is put to be brutally beaten by Lord Rajasena ([[Sarunyu Wongkrajang]])'s men. He is helped to recover by Master Bua ([[Nirut Sirijanya]]), and when Tien returns to his village, he finds it taken over by Bhuti Sangkha ([[Dan Chupong]]). ==Plot== In the year 1431 in Thailand, Tien ([[Tony Jaa]]) is held captive being beaten with wooden [[stick fighting|staves]]. On the orders of Lord Rajasena ([[Sarunyu Wongkrajang]]), his elbows and knees are snapped. As Lord Rajasena sleeps, Tien's guerilla fighters attempt to free Tien, but Bhuti Sangkha ([[Dan Chupong]]) appears and kills them. Lord Rajasena offers to hire Bhuti, but he refuses and gives the offer to remove the curse which has been placed on Rajasena before leaving. Rajasena orders his men to kill Tien, but before this can be carried out, a man arrives with a pardon from the king, indicating that he will take Tien, much to Rajasena's ire. The messenger returns Tien to the Kana Khone villagers. After fending off the village from invaders who are after Tien, Master Bua ([[Nirut Sirijanya]]) feels guilty over Tien's imprisonment and becomes a [[bhikkhu|Buddhist monk]]. Pim ([[Primrata Det-Udom]]) heals Tien to life, but finds that Tien is still crippled from his beatings. Tien then embarks on a rehabilitation regimen with the help of Master Bua. Rajasena visits Bhuti at his temple to remove his curse, but Bhuti reveals his true motive of usurping Rajasena and becoming the new king. After a battle, Bhuti decapitates Rajasena, but his severed head curses Bhuti. After meditating, Tien returns to his village to find it in ruins, and the surviving villagers kidnapped and enslaved by Bhuti. Bhuti uses his magic to summon an eclipse. When Pim reveals herself as Tien's companion, she is taken to Bhuti's palace, where she is killed. Tien witnesses this killing from a statue and fights his way through the guards before confronting Bhuti, who launches a spear at Tien's chest. As he falls to his knees, defeated, he remembers Bua's words, and finds himself again atop the statue. Overcoming Bhuti's illusion, lightning strikes and Bhuti's eclipse magic is dispelled. Bhuti attempts to escape but is confronted by Tien. Bhuti attempts again to throw a spear at Tien, who catches and throws it aside. On the royal ledge above the arena, Tien's upright finger tips hold Bhuti aloft by his chin. Suddenly an elephant's trunk butts the doors below the ledge, causing Bhuti to fall from Tien's grasp. Bhuti falls, over the elephant's tusks. The camera pans as we watch Bhuti dying on the ground, pierced by the elephant's broken tusk. As he breaths his last breath, the elephant, now resembling the one tusk [[Ganesha]], raises his head in a victorious trumpet. Beginning life anew, with good having triumphed over evil, the final scene opens as Tien, Pim and the remaining villagers, pray before the statue of Ong Bak. == Cast == * [[Tony Jaa]] as Tien * [[Primorata Dejudom]] as Pim * [[Dan Chupong]] as Bhuti Sangkha / Crow Ghost (as Chupong Chungpruk) * [[Sarunyoo Wongkrachang]] as Lord Jom Rajasena. * [[Nirut Sirijanya]] as Master Phra Bua * [[Petchtai Wongkamlao]] as Mhen (as Phetthai Wongkhamlao) * [[Chumphorn Thepphithak]] as Uncle Mao * [[Supakorn Kitsuwon]] as Golden-Armoured King's Guard * [[Sorapong Chatree]] as Chernang * [[Santisuk Promsiri]] as Lord Sihadecho ==Production== After the first two weeks of ''[[Ong Bak 2]]'' theatrical release, the president of [[Sahamongkol Film]] announced their intention of a sequel. Filming of new footage for the follow-up was to begin before the end of the year and was to incorporate unused footage from ''Ong Bak 2''.{{cite web | last = Pajee | first = Parinyaporn | title = Back on Track | publisher = Daily Xpress | date = 2008-12-18 | url = http://www.dailyxpress.net/2008/12/18/entertainment/entertainment_5163.php | accessdate = 2008-12-18 }} ==Release== ''Ong Bak 3'' was released in Thailand on May 5, 2010.{{cite web|title=Ong Bak 3 (‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡πå‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏Å 3)|work=Film Business Asia|accessdate=January 7, 2011|author=Elley, Derek|date=May 18, 2010|url=http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/ong-bak-3|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524172048/http://www.filmbiz.asia/reviews/ong-bak-3|archivedate=May 24, 2010|df=}} On its first week it played in 135 theaters in Thailand and was the second highest grossing film in the Thai box office, earning $555,823.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/thailand/?yr=2010&wk=19&p=.htm|title=Thailand Box Office, May 6‚Äì9, 2010|accessdate=January 7, 2011|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]}} ''Ong Bak 3'' earned $1,335,646 during its theatrical run in Thailand and grossed a total of $2,325,473 with foreign markets.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=ongbak3.htm|work=Box Office Mojo|title=Ong Bak 3 (2011) - International Box Office Results|accessdate=January 7, 2011}} This was less successful than ''[[Ong Bak 2]]'', which had made $8,936,663 in total.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/default.htm?id=ongbak2.htm|title=Ong Bak 2: The Beginning (2009) - Box Office Mojo|work=Box Office Mojo}} ''Ong Bak 3'' had its North American premiere at [[Fantastic Fest]] on September 23, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://twitchfilm.com/news/2010/08/fantastic-fest-unleases-its-second-wave-of-programming.php|work=[[Twitch Film]]|title=News: Fantastic Fest Unleashes It's Second Wave of Programming|author=Smithson, Sean|date=August 2010|accessdate=January 7, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://fantasticfest.bside.com/2010/films/ongbak3_tonyjaa_fantasticfest2010|title=Fantastic Fest 2010: Ong Bak 3|author=Walkow, Marc|accessdate=January 7, 2011|work=Fantastic Fest}} The film was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] in Australia on November 8, 2010, and in the United States on February 8, 2011. ==Reception== The film has received generally negative reviews. Both ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' and Film Business Asia praised the action scenes but pointed out the weak story. Film Business Asia gave the film a five out of ten rating praising the action sequences but finding that it made ''Ong Bak 2'' "look like a masterpiece of character development." ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' and ''[[Total Film]]'' found the film spent too much focus on Buddhist philosophy that left not enough time for the action scenes.{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117943156?refcatid=31|title=Variety Reviews - Ong Bak 3 - Film Reviews|author=Kuipers, Richard|date=July 13, 2010|accessdate=January 7, 2011|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} ''Total Film'' awarded the film two stars out of five, stating that "a greater focus on Buddhist philosophy...leaves little room for the sort of bone-crunching, no-frills set-pieces that first brought Jaa to our attention."{{cite web|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/reviews/dvd/ong-bak-3|title=Ong Bak 3|work=[[Total Film]]|date=November 22, 2010|accessdate=January 7, 2011|author=Jordan, Richard}} ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' gave the film three stars out of four praising it as "easily the most brutal of all the contemporary Thai martial arts films that have come to the U.S. thus far. But that's what characterizes the Thai style of fighting films: inspired excess and decadence."{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/ong-bak-3/5239|work=[[Slant Magazine]]|title=Ong Bak 3 : Film Review: Slant Magazine|accessdate=January 29, 2011|author=Abrams, Simon}} ==Video game== ''Ong Bak Tri'' is being developed by Studio Hive and will be published worldwide by Immanitas Entertainment for PC, smartphones, [[PlayStation Network]], and [[Xbox Live Marketplace]]. It will be a 2.5D side-scrolling brawler with "intense fighting action, impressive free-running sequences, and highly cinematic quick-time action events," according to the press release. The game, like the second and third films, is set in ancient Thailand. No official release date has been announced.{{cite web |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2012/12/06/ong-bak-tri-the-video-game-trailer-shows-off-that-unity3d-engine-with-some-flair/ |title=''Ong Bak Tri: The Video Game'' Trailer Shows Off That Unity3D Engine with Some Flair |author=Ravenscraft, Eric |publisher=''Android Police'' |date=2012-12-06 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-hive-mind-behind-the-ong-bak-video-game/1100-6402872/ |title=The Hive Mind Behind the ''Ong Bak'' Video Game |author=Leo, Jon |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |date=2013-01-29 |accessdate=2014-01-22}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.ongbak3film.com/}} * {{Amg title|521549}} * {{mojo title|ongbak3}} * {{IMDb title|1653690}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|ong_bak_3}} {{Panna Rittikrai}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:2010s action films]] [[Category:2010s prequel films]] [[Category:Sequel films]] [[Category:Prequel films]] [[Category:Thai films]] [[Category:Thai-language films]] [[Category:Films set in the 15th century]] [[Category:Martial arts films]] [[Category:Muay Thai films]] [[Category:Sahamongkol Film International films]] [[Category:Supernatural thriller films]]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Peter Pan]] to [[Category:Works based on Peter Pan]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox play|name=Peter Pan Goes Wrong |image= |image_size= |image_alt= |caption= |writer=Henry Lewis, Jonathan Sayer and [[Henry Shields]]
Based on ''[[Peter and Wendy|Peter Pan]]'' by [[J.M. Barrie]] |chorus= |characters= |mute= |setting= |premiere=10 December 2013 |place=Pleasance Theatre, London |orig_lang=English |series= |subject= |genre=Comedy |web=http://www.peterpangoeswrong.com/ }} '''''Peter Pan Goes Wrong''''' is a play by Henry Lewis, Jonathan Sayer, and [[Henry Shields]] of the [[Mischief Theatre|Mischief Theatre Company]] (creators of ''[[The Play That Goes Wrong]]''). The premise, as in ''The Play That Goes Wrong'', is that the actors and crews are members of the fictitious Cornley Polytechnic Drama Society presenting their production of the [[J. M. Barrie|J.M. Barrie]] classic ''[[Peter and Wendy|Peter Pan]]'', and ruin it through amateurism and personal rivalries. == Production history == The play made its premiere at the Pleasance Theatre in [[London]] in December 2013 before touring the UK in 2014. The production transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]] in London at the [[Apollo Theatre]] for a Christmas season run in 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/reviews/peter-pan-goes-wrong-apollo-theatre_39315.html |title=Peter Pan Goes Wrong (Apollo Theatre)|work=What's On Stage|date=10 December 2015|accessdate=2018-01-01 }} It featured the original cast of ''The Play That Goes Wrong'' reprising their cast and crew characters from the original production, with the addition of Ellie Morris as Robert's niece Lucy, who is subjected to increasingly serious injuries over the course of the show. It returned to the Apollo Theatre the following year for another Christmas season run from October 2016 making it the third show running in the West End from the Mischief Theatre Company after ''The Play That Goes Wrong'' and [[The Comedy About a Bank Robbery|''The Comedy About A Bank Robbery'']]. [[Great Ormond Street Hospital]] Children's Charity benefited from royalties of the play, in accordance to the terms of the [[Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988]] which granted them a right to royalty in perpetuity from adaptations of the story of ''[[Peter and Wendy|Peter Pan]]'' on stage, publication and film in the UK. == Reception == Like ''The Play That Goes Wrong'', ''Peter Pan Goes Wrong'' received positive reviews. [[WhatsOnStage.com]] gave it five out of five stars. The original West End run was nominated for the 2016 Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Comedy but lost to [[Nell Gwynn (play)|''Nell Gwynn'']].{{Cite web|url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/latest-news/article/item358563/nell-gwynn-wins-olivier/|title=Nell Gwynn wins Olivier|website=www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-08}} == Television special == The play was adapted into a one-hour television special which was broadcast on 31 December 2016 on BBC One, guest-starring [[David Suchet]] as the narrator.{{cite news|author=Georgina Littlejohn |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/2495280/when-is-peter-pan-goes-wrong-on-tv-whos-in-the-cast-and-where-can-i-see-the-play/ |title=When is Peter Pan Goes Wrong on TV? Who‚Äôs in the cast and where can I see the play?|work=The Sun|date=29 December 2016|accessdate=2018-01-01 }} and featuring the original cast, with the exception of Rob Falconer. It was filmed in front of a live audience at [[Pinewood Studios]]{{cite news|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/news/peter-pan-goes-wrong-bbc-tv-broadcast_41543.html |title=Peter Pan Goes Wrong to be broadcast on the BBC this Christmas|work=What's On Stage|date=15 August 2016|accessdate=2018-01-01 }} and featured additional footage of other BBC television sets being accidentally invaded. == See also == * ''[[The Play That Goes Wrong]]'' == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official|http://www.peterpangoeswrong.com/}} {{Peter Pan|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Play That Goes Wrong}} [[Category:West End plays]] [[Category:2013 plays]] [[Category:Sequel plays]] [[Category:Plays based on other plays]] [[Category:Works based on Peter Pan]] [[Category:Mischief Theatre]]

{{lead too short|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = Piranha | image = Piranha 3d poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Alexandre Aja]] | producer = Alexandre Aja
[[Mark Canton]]
Marc Toberoff
[[Gr√©gory Levasseur]] | writer = Pete Goldfinger
[[Josh Stolberg]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[Piranha (1978 film)|Piranha]]''|John Sayles}} | starring = [[Elisabeth Shue]]
[[Adam Scott (actor)|Adam Scott]]
[[Jerry O'Connell]]
[[Ving Rhames]]
[[Jessica Szohr]]
[[Steven R. McQueen]]
[[Christopher Lloyd]]
[[Richard Dreyfuss]] | music = [[Michael Wandmacher]] | cinematography = [[John R. Leonetti]] | editing = Baxter | studio = [[The Weinstein Company]]
Atmosphere Entertainment
Chako Film Company
Intellectual Properties Worldwide | distributor = [[Dimension Films]] | released = {{Film date|2010|8|20}} | runtime = 88 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $24 million | gross = $83.1 million{{cite web | url = http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=piranha3d.htm| title = Piranha 3D (2010) | publisher =[[Amazon.com]]| work =[[Box Office Mojo]]| accessdate = 2015-05-10 }} }} '''''Piranha 3D''''' is a 2010 American [[3D film|3D]] [[comedy horror|comedy horror film]] that serves as a loose [[Remake#Film|remake]] of the horror film ''[[Piranha (1978 film)|Piranha]]'' (1978) and an entry in the [[Piranha (film series)|''Piranha'' film series]]. It was directed by [[Alexandre Aja]] and has an [[ensemble cast]] featuring [[Elisabeth Shue]], [[Adam Scott (actor)|Adam Scott]], [[Jerry O'Connell]], [[Ving Rhames]], [[Steven R. McQueen]], [[Jessica Szohr]], [[Christopher Lloyd]], [[Richard Dreyfuss]], [[Dina Meyer]], [[Kelly Brook]], [[Riley Steele]] and [[Eli Roth]]. A sequel, [[Piranha 3DD]], was released in 2012. ==Plot== Fisherman Matt Boyd ([[Richard Dreyfuss]]) is fishing in Lake Victoria when a small [[earthquake]] hits, splitting the lake floor and causing a whirlpool. Boyd falls in, and is ripped apart by a school of [[piranha]]s that emerge from the chasm. Jake Forester ([[Steven R. McQueen]]) is admiring attractive tourists as [[spring break]] begins. He reunites with his old crush Kelly Driscoll ([[Jessica Szohr]]) and meets her arrogant boyfriend who soaks Jake with a slush drink. Jake then meets Derrick Jones ([[Jerry O'Connell]]), a sleazy pornographer, as well as Danni Arslow ([[Kelly Brook]]), one of his actresses. Derrick convinces Jake to show him good spots on the lake for filming a pornographic movie. That night, Jake's mother, Sheriff Julie Forester ([[Elisabeth Shue]]), searches for the missing Matt Boyd with Deputy Fallon ([[Ving Rhames]]). They find his mutilated body and contemplate closing the lake. However, this decision is made difficult as two-thousand partying college students are on [[spring break]], which is important for bringing revenue to the small town. The next morning, a lone cliff diver is attacked and consumed by the vicious, marauding piranhas. Jake bribes his sister, Laura ([[Brooklynn Proulx]]), and brother, Zane (Sage Ryan), to stay home alone so that he can show Derrick around the lake. After Jake leaves, Zane convinces Laura to go fishing on a small sandbar island. They forget to tie the boat down and are stranded in the middle of the lake. Meanwhile, Jake goes to meet with Derrick and runs into Kelly, who accepted Derrick's invitation on board his boat, ''The Barracuda''. Jake meets Crystal Shepard ([[Riley Steele]]), another one of Derrick's actresses, and cameraman Andrew Cunningham ([[Paul Scheer]]). Julie takes a team of [[seismologist]] divers‚ÄîNovak Radzinsky ([[Adam Scott (actor)|Adam Scott]]), Sam Montez ([[Ricardo Chavira]]), and Paula Montellano ([[Dina Meyer]]) to the fissure. Novak speculates that the rift leads to a buried prehistoric lake. Paula and Sam [[scuba dive]] to the bottom and discover a large cavern filled with large piranha egg stocks. Both are killed by the piranhas before they can alert the others to the discovery. Novak and Julie find Paula's corpse and pull it onto the boat, capturing a lone piranha, which they take to Carl Goodman ([[Christopher Lloyd]]), a retired [[marine biologist]] who runs a pet store and aquarium shop. He explains that it is a highly aggressive prehistoric species, long believed to be extinct, and that the piranhas have survived through [[cannibalism]]. The species is able to vigorously devour its prey in seconds. Julie, Novak, Fallon, and Deputy Taylor Roberts try to evacuate the lake, but their warnings are ignored, until the piranhas begin to fiercely attack the tourists. Novak boards a [[jet-ski]] with a [[shotgun]] to help while Fallon drags people to shore, and Julie and Taylor try to get swimmers into the police boat. Almost everyone, in the lake is either wounded, dismembered, or killed by the piranhas altogether, including Kelly's boyfriend. The remaining tourists escape as the party spot rapidly turns into a bloodbath. Meanwhile, Jake spots Laura and Zane on the island and forces Derrick to rescue them. Derrick crashes the boat into some rocks, flooding the boat's lower deck and causing the boat to begin sinking. Kelly is trapped in the kitchen while Derrick, Crystal and Andrew fall overboard from the impact of the collision. Crystal is eaten, and Andrew escapes to shore unharmed. Meanwhile, Danni manages to get a partially eaten Derrick back on board, where he then dies. Deputy Fallon makes a last stand, taking a boat motor and using its propeller to shred many piranhas, though he is presumed to be killed by the piranhas. After the chaos settles, Julie receives a call from Jake pleading for help. Julie and Novak steal a speedboat and head off towards the kids. They reach Jake and attach a rope to his boat. Julie, Danni, Laura and Zane start crossing the rope, but the piranhas latch onto Danni's hair, causing her to lose her grip on the rope and fall into the water, where she is quickly devoured. The others make it across safely, but the rope comes loose. Using Derrick's corpse as a distraction, Jake ties the line to himself and goes to save Kelly. He ties Kelly to him and lights a flare after releasing the gas from a pair of stored propane tanks. Novak starts the boat and speeds away just as the piranhas surround Kelly and Jake. They are dragged to safety as the [[propane]] tanks explode, destroying the boat and killing most of the piranhas. Mr. Goodman calls Julie on the radio, and Julie tells him that they seem to have killed the majority of the piranhas. A horrified Goodman tells her that the reproductive glands on the piranha they obtained were not mature, which means that the fish they have killed were only the babies. As Novak wonders aloud where the parents are, the human sized-piranha queen leaps out of the water and eats him. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Elisabeth Shue]] as Sheriff Julie Forester * [[Steven R. McQueen]] as Jake Forester * [[Adam Scott (actor)|Adam Scott]] as Novak Radzinsky * [[Jerry O'Connell]] as Derrick Jones * [[Jessica Szohr]] as Kelly Driscoll * [[Kelly Brook]] as Danni Arslow * [[Riley Steele]] as Crystal Shepard * [[Ving Rhames]] as Deputy Fallon * [[Dina Meyer]] as Paula Montellano * [[Christopher Lloyd]] as Carl Goodman * [[Richard Dreyfuss]] as Matt Boyd * [[Ricardo Chavira]] as Sam Montez * [[Paul Scheer]] as Andrew Cunningham * [[Cody Longo]] as Todd Dupree * Sage Ryan as Zane Forester * [[Brooklynn Proulx]] as Laura Forester * Devra Korwin as Mrs. Goodman * [[Jesse Pruett]] as Spring Break Party Student {{div col end}} Richard Dreyfuss said that he accepted the role after [[Bob Weinstein]] persuaded him by offering him a larger salary, which Dreyfuss later donated to charity. Dreyfuss also stated that the ill-fated character he plays is a parody and a near-reincarnation of Matt Hooper, the character he portrayed in the film ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'' (1975), with whom his character shares the same first name.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodnews.com/2010/05/05/richard-dreyfuss-reveals-why-he-made-%E2%80%98piranha-3-d%E2%80%99-%E2%80%9Cto-get-money%E2%80%9D/|title=Richard Dreyfuss reveals why he made ‚ÄòPiranha 3-D:' "to get money";‚Äì Film.com|accessdate=August 19, 2010|publisher=Film.com}} ''Jaws'' later served as inspiration for the parody film entitled ''[[Piranha (1978 film)|Piranha]]''. The song the character in ''Piranha 3D'' listens to on the radio on his boat is "[[Show Me the Way to Go Home]]", which Richard Dreyfuss, [[Roy Scheider]] and [[Robert Shaw (actor)|Robert Shaw]] sing together aboard Quint's boat the ''Orca'' in ''Jaws''. [[Eli Roth]], [[Ashlynn Brooke]], [[Bonnie Morgan]], Genevieve Alexandra and [[Gianna Michaels]] appear as spring breakers who meet gruesome demises, while [[Franck Khalfoun]] and [[Jason Spisak]] portray deputies. ==Production== [[Chuck Russell]] was originally scheduled to direct the film, and made uncredited rewrites to the script by [[Josh Stolberg]] and Peter Goldfinger, as well as incorporating the original John Sayles script that Joe Dante directed the first time around.{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117924015.html?categoryid=13&cs=1|title=Chiller chomps ''Piranha''|last=Fleming|first=Michael|date=June 6, 2005|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=2008-10-26}} Alexandre Aja was selected to direct the film instead.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18701 |title=Attack of the 'Piranha'! Massive Richard Dreyfus Scoop, Tons of Meaty Images! |publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|date=2010-01-14 |accessdate=2010-07-24}} Production on the film was scheduled to begin late 2008, but was delayed until March 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/news/topnews.php?id=7683|title=Aja Doesn't Start ''Piranha'' Until '09|date=September 10, 2008|publisher=ShockTillYouDrop.com|accessdate=2008-10-26}} In October 2008, Aja stated filming would begin in the spring. He further stated "It's such a difficult movie, not only because of the technicality of it and the [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] fish, but also because it all happens in a lake. We were supposed to start shooting now, but the longer to leave it the colder the water gets. The movie takes place during [[Spring Break]] and, of course, the studio wanted it ready for the summer, but if you've got 1,000 people who need to get murdered in the water, you have to wait for the right temperature for the water, for the weather, for everything."{{cite web|url=https://editorial.rottentomatoes.com/article/exclusive-alexandre-aja-talks-mirrors-and-piranha-3d/|title=Exclusive: Alexandre Aja talks Mirrors and Piranha 3D|last=Utichi |first=Joe|date=October 10, 2008|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=2017-11-05}} Shooting took place in June 2009 at Bridgewater Channel in [[Lake Havasu]], located in [[Lake Havasu City, Arizona]]. The water was also dyed red for the shooting.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18200 |title='Piranha 3D' Test Screened, Bloodiest Movie Ever? |publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=2010-07-24}} Citing constraints with 3D camera rigs, Aja shot ''Piranha'' in 2D and [[2D to 3D conversion|converted to 3D in post production]] using a 3D conversion process developed by Michael Roderick and used by the company, Inner-D.{{cite web|url=http://www.inner-d.com|title=Inner-D|publisher=Inner-D|date=2010-08-20|accessdate=2010-08-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823090051/http://www.inner-d.com/|archivedate=2010-08-23|df=}} Unlike some other 3D converted films released in 2010, ''Piranha'''s conversion was not done as an afterthought, and it was one of the first post-conversion processes to be well received by critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.criticsnotebook.com/2010/08/piranha-3d-alexandre-aja-movie-review.html|title=Death Fish, Piranha 3D Movie Review |publisher=Critics Notebook|date=2010-08-20 |accessdate=2010-08-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cinematical.com/2010/08/20/review-piranha-3d/|title=Piranha 3D Movie Reivew |publisher=Cinematical|date=2010-08-20 |accessdate=2010-08-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.filmschoolrejects.com/features/kevin-carr%E2%80%99s-weekly-report-card-august-20-2010.php |title=Kevin Carr's Weekly Report Card: August 20, 2010 |publisher=Film School Rejects|date=2010-08-20 |accessdate=2010-08-21}} ==Release== ''Piranha 3D''{{'}}s theatrical release date had been set for April 16, 2010, but was delayed.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/35364/weinsteins-push-piranha-3d-back-at-least-four-months |title=Weinsteins Push Piranha 3D Back At Least Four Months |publisher=[[Dread Central]]|date=2010-01-15|accessdate=2010-07-24}} The film was planned to premiere on August 27, 2010,{{cite web | url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2010/01/weinstein-cos-piranha-3d-isnt-going-to-be-biting-anyone-for-awhile.html|title=Weinstein Co.'s 'Piranha 3-D' isn't going to be biting anyone for a while |work=[[LA Times]]| date=2010-01-14 | accessdate=2010-01-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18710 |title='Piranha 3D' Has its Ass Kicked Out of April |publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|date= |accessdate=2010-07-24}} but in June 2010 was moved to August 20, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37956/piranha-3d-spawns-a-new-release-date |title=Piranha 3D Spawns a New Release Date |publisher=[[Dread Central]]|date= |accessdate=2010-07-24}} The film's first trailer debuted with ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]''. A second trailer was shown in prints of ''[[A Nightmare on Elm Street (2010 film)|A Nightmare on Elm Street]]'' and ''[[Inception]]''. It was set to have a panel on 24 July 2010 as part of the [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] but was cancelled after convention organizers decided the footage that was planned to be shown was not appropriate.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38468/sd-comic-con-10-schedules-updated-piranha-3d-panel-disappears |title=SD Comic-Con '10 Schedules Updated; Piranha 3D Panel Disappears! |publisher=[[Dread Central]]|accessdate=2010-07-24}} Nine minutes of footage, with some unfinished effects, were leaked onto websites. The clip used in promotional TV ads and the trailer that shows [[Jessica Szohr]]'s character, Kelly, face to face with a pack of piranhas was not used in the movie, and was used for promotion only. The official poster was released June 22, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://thefilmstage.com/2010/06/23/first-poster-for-%E2%80%98piranha-3d%E2%80%99/|title=First Poster for Piranha 3D|work=''thefilmstage.com''|accessdate=June 22, 2010|date=June 22, 2010}} ===Box office=== ''Piranha 3D'' grossed $10,106,872 in its first 3 days, opening at #6 in the United States box office.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/charts/weekly/2010/20100820.php|title=North American Box Office Chart for August 20‚Äì22, 2010|work=''the-numbers.com''|accessdate=September 16, 2010|date=September 16, 2010}} In the United Kingdom, ''Piranha 3D'' opened at #4 at the box office, earning ¬£1,487,119. As of May 16, 2011, Piranha 3D has made $83,188,165 worldwide.[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=piranha3d.htm "Pirahna 3D"]. [[boxofficemojo]] ===Reception=== ''Piranha 3D'' received generally positive reviews. It is certified "fresh" on the review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] with an approval rating of 73% and an average score of 6.2 out of 10, based on 120 reviews. The consensus reads "Playing exactly to expectations for a movie about killer fish run amok, ''Piranha 3-D'' dishes out gore, guffaws and gratuitous nudity with equal glee."{{cite web| url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/piranha_3d/| title = Piranha 3D Movie Reviews, Pictures| work =[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Flixster]]|accessdate=11 May 2011}} On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Standard score|normalized]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the film has received a score of 53, based on 20 reviews, which indicates "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web | url= http://www.metacritic.com/movie/piranha-3-d | title=Piranha 3-D (2010): Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]]| publisher= [[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=11 May 2011}} A tongue-in-cheek scholarly review of the movie was written for the journal ''Copeia'' (Chakrabarty & Fink 2011), which reviewed the movie as if it were a documentary film.Chakrabarty, P., and Fink, W.L. (2011) [Review of] Piranha 3D. Copeia 2011 (1): 181 [http://www.asihcopeiaonline.org/doi/full/10.1643/OT-10-147. "Pirahna 3D"]. asihcopeiaonline.org ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "Remember the film you hoped ''[[Snakes on a Plane]]'' would be ‚Äì this is it! By any sane cinematic standards, meretricious trash ... but thrown at you with such good-humoured glee that it's hard to resist. It's a bumper-sticker of a movie: honk if you love tits and gore! Honk honk honk."{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/review.asp?FID=133204 |title=Piranha 3D |publisher=Empireonline.com |date=2006-12-05 |accessdate=2010-09-22}} [[Christy Lemire]], film critic for the [[Associated Press]], said "Run, don't walk: ''Piranha 3D'' is hilariously, cleverly gory. Mere words cannot describe how awesomely gnarly ''Piranha 3D'' is, how hugely entertaining, and how urgently you must get yourself to the theatre to see it. Like, now."{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sns-bc-us--filmreview-piranha3d,0,1525852.story|title=Piranha 3D review|publisher=[[LA Times]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825214703/http://www.latimes.com/sns-bc-us--filmreview-piranha3d,0,1525852.story|archivedate=August 25, 2010}} HollywoodLife.com called the film "a campy masterpiece of a movie", adding "If you have an ounce of fun in your body, you will love this movie about killer piranhas that overtake a town of hotties{{spaced ndash}}in 3D!"{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodlife.com/2010/08/19/piranha-3d-jerry-oconnell-vampires-diaries-steve-mcqueen-jessica-szohr-gossip-girl-christopher-lloyd-back-to-the-future-doc-brow/ |title=Piranha 3D Review |publisher=Hollywood Life |date=2010-08-19 |accessdate=2010-09-22}} Peter Hall of Cinematical.com said "The gore, the nudity, the language, the gags, the characters{{spaced ndash}}it's all always on the rise. Just when you think things could not possibly get more ridiculous, that the film has peaked, Aja and screenwriters Pete Goldfinger and Josh Stolberg manage to ram another syringe of adrenaline into its heart."{{cite web|last=Hall |first=Peter |url=http://www.cinematical.com/2010/08/20/review-piranha-3d/ |title=Piranha 3D Review |publisher=Cinematical.com |date=2010-08-20 |accessdate=2010-09-22}} ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' referred to the film as "a pitch-perfect, guilty-pleasure serving of late-summer schlock that handily nails the tongue-in-cheek spirit of the Roger Corman original" while stating "''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'' it ain't{{spaced ndash}}Aja exhibits little patience for such stuff as dramatic tension and tautly coiled suspense, and there are some undeniable choppy bits...but he never loses sight of the potential fun factor laid out in Pete Goldfinger and Josh Stolberg's script."{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/film-reviews/piranha-3d-film-review-1004110347.story |title=Piranha 3D ‚Äì Film Review |author=Rechtshaffen, Michael |accessdate=August 21, 2010 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820102608/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/film-reviews/piranha-3d-film-review-1004110347.story |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |df= }} The ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of four, stating that "''Piranha 3D'' goes for the jugular. And generally misses, but generally in an amusing way."{{cite web |url= http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/piranha_3d/?critic=creamcrop |author= Moore, Roger |accessdate= August 21, 2010 |title= Movie Review: Piranha 3D |work=Orlando Sentinel|date= August 20, 2010}} ===Home media=== The film was released on DVD, [[Blu-ray]], and Blu-ray [[3D film|3D]] formats on Tuesday, January 11, 2011. The "3D" part of the title was taken off the [[Two-dimensional space|2D]] releases to prevent confusion of the two formats. The film was released in Australia on Thursday, December 30, 2010. The film was shown on British television on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] on February 10, 2013 for the first time, and in 2D format. ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Piranha 3D: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = Various artists | cover = Piranha 3D Original Motion Picture Score (Official Album Cover).jpg | alt = | released = {{Start date|2010|08|31}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 42:47 | label = [[Lakeshore Records]] LKS 341872 | producer = [[Skip Williamson (producer)|Skip Williamson]] ([[Executive producer|exec.]]), [[Brian McNelis]] (exec.) | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} Lakeshore Records released the soundtrack album of Piranha 3D which included mostly [[rap]], [[dance (music)|dance]], [[hip-hop]] and [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] music. [[Zuper Blahq]] | length12 = 3:24 }} ===Songs not included on the soundtrack=== * "[[Show Me the Way to Go Home]]" by [[Mitch Miller|Mitch Miller & The Gang]] * "I'm Not a Whore" by [[LMFAO (group)|LMFAO]] * "Fetish" by [[Far East Movement]] * "Girls on the Dance Floor" by [[Far East Movement]] ===Credits=== * A&r [Director] ‚Äì Eric Craig * Cello [Electric Cello], Guitar, Percussion, Programmed By ‚Äì Michael Wandmacher * Composed By ‚Äì Susie Benchasil Seiter * Conductor ‚Äì Michael Wandmacher * Edited By [Music] ‚Äì Joshua Winget * Executive Producer [Executive Producer For Lakeshore Records] ‚Äì Brian McNelis, Skip Williamson * Mixed By ‚Äì Mark Curry (3) * Orchestrated By ‚Äì Chad Seiter, Michael Wandmacher, Susie Benchasil Seiter * Producer ‚Äì Michael Wandmacher ==Sequel== {{Main|Piranha 3DD}} [[Dimension Films]] announced a [[sequel]] shortly after the first film was released.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=69034|title=Dimension Films Announces Piranha 3D Sequel ‚Äì ComingSoon.net|publisher=ComingSoon.net|accessdate=August 22, 2010|date=August 22, 2010}} The film is ''[[Piranha 3DD]]'' and is directed by [[John Gulager]] with [[Patrick Melton]] and [[Marcus Dunstan]] writing. It was released on June 1, 2012. It stars [[Danielle Panabaker]], [[Matt Bush (actor)|Matt Bush]], [[David Koechner]], [[Chris Zylka]], [[Katrina Bowden]] and [[Gary Busey]], with [[Ving Rhames]], [[Paul Scheer]] and [[Christopher Lloyd]] reprising their roles from ''Piranha 3D''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/41471/ving-rhames-swim-fishes-again-piranha-3dd|title= Ving Rhames to Swim With the Fishes Again in Piranha 3DD? |publisher=[[DreadCentral.com]]|date=December 16, 2011|accessdate=December 17, 2011}} ''Piranha 3DD'' is set at a waterpark where the piranhas find a way through the pipes.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/23996|title='Piranha 3 Double D' Meat Eaters Swim Into a Waterpark!|work=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|date=March 29, 2011}} Following its release, it failed to generate the positive critical reaction of its predecessor and grossed only $8,493,728.[http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=piranha3dd.htm "Pirahna 3DD"]. {{Infobox video game | title = Pridefest | collapsible = | state = | image = Pridefest banner art.jpg | caption = ''Pridefest'' logo | developer = Vertigo Arts | publisher = [[Atari, Inc. (Atari, SA subsidiary)|Atari, Inc.]] | series = | engine = | platforms = [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] | released = January 27, 2016 | genre = [[Social simulation game|Social simulation]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] }} '''''Pridefest''''' is a [[social simulation game]]. [[Atari, Inc. (Atari, SA subsidiary)|Atari, Inc.]] announced the game on July 17, 2014 shortly after the company sponsored and participated in [[GaymerX2]].<ref name="ataripr714">{{cite press release |url=http://www.atari.com/news/atari-leads-march-pridefest-new-lgbt-themed-game-coming-soon | title=Atari¬Æ Leads the March with Pridefest‚Ñ¢, a New LGBT-Themed Game Coming Soon | publisher=Atari, Inc. | date=July 17, 2014 | accessdate=August 14, 2014}}</ref> The game is for [[tablet computer]]s operating [[iOS]] or [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. The game was released on January 27, 2016.<ref name="wiredcouk714">{{cite news |url=http://www.cbs19.tv/story/31068847/atari-launches-pridefest-mobile-game-celebrating-lgbtq-equality-marches-onto-iphone-ipad-ipod-touch-and-android-devices | title=LGBT sim Pridefest marks Atari's equality push | work=Wired.co.uk | date=July 23, 2014 | accessdate=August 14, 2014 | author=Kamen, Matt}}</ref><ref name="time714">{{cite news |url=http://time.com/3001453/atari-unveils-pridefest-an-lgbt-themed-social-sim-game/ | title=Atari Unveils Pridefest, an LGBT-Themed Social Sim Game | work=Time | date=July 17, 2014 | accessdate=August 14, 2014 | author=Peckham, Matt}}</ref>
==Gameplay== Players are able to launch and manage a [[LGBT pride parade]] in a city of their choosing. They can customize parade floats by choosing size, components, mascots and decorations, as well as surrounding structures and side attractions, which then factor into a city happiness metric. Players can complete quests or challenge goals to unlock new parades, receive festival supplies or secure bonuses. Social elements of the game include avatar customization, chatting with friends and the ability to bring your parade to a friend's city, or to join in on a friend's parade.<ref name="ataripr714" /><ref name="wiredcouk714" /><ref name="time714" /> Atari does not plan to include the political aspects of LGBT pride parades. According to the company, "Pridefest will be a fun, social game first and foremost. We do not have a political component in the game."<ref name="wiredcouk714" />
==Development== This is the first LGBT-themed video game from Atari, Inc. and their second major outreach to the LGBT gaming community after sponsoring and participating in [[GaymerX2]].<ref name="ataripr714" /> The company is putting together an advisory board that includes people from the [[Gaymer|LGBT gamer]] community to help avoid stereotypes and "to develop an engaging and fun game that is inclusive to all gamers".<ref name="wiredcouk714" />
